First things first!! I am NOT a hardcore viewer of the series and have not seen the first movie. I have seen a few episodes. So I decided to see this movie. I was very much expecting a terrible move so I went with a closed mind. I was glad that I did because that's why I absolutely LOVED SATC part 2! However, it should have been called "Things to do in the Middle East if you're a millionaire." You read that right, there is a lot of stuff that is all related to the middle east. The best parts of the movie were all shot at the beginning. I was laughing so hard at that wedding. The wedding must have cost at least 1 million dollars. The other good part in the movie was when that Danish guy stood up and was yelled at by the mean person from the middle east. I also liked it when Charlotte looked over at the three men and saw that Irish lady being gawked at! As for the Chris Noth Character - BIG, he was not in this enough but then again, maybe he was. He talked in a VERY IRRITATING way to his wife each time he spoke. I was not thrilled. I like NOTH but prefer to see him in Law and Order. I liked the cameo by the person who was in THE PRETENDER.

Review title: Superficial pandering to all women that was just disgusting
Review_body: It's two years later, I've become much more cynical about "Sex and the City", and each of the 4 girls is having problems in their shallow, designed life. The quality of the writing is decreasing rapidly. These are barely even characters anymore, just stick-figures to hang dresses on and caricatures of their audience. The film-makers are just pandering to women between the ages of 30 and 60 and finding superficial things in the characters for them to relate to. I was disgusted by their constant ass-kissing of their target audience. It was very unnatural, but then again at least they know their target audience, somewhat.Of course the depiction of Abu Dhabi was superficial, but that was to be expected. The entire point of this film was for women to feel empowered and to want to buy expensive clothes. For those of us who see through the disgusting glam, that point is hanging on a very thin understanding of women.Despite the poor writing and embarrassing attempt to please all women, the actors were still able to connect me to these characters and keep me emotionally invested throughout. I was watching because I knew Aidan (John Corbett) was back. They gave me most of the things I wanted to hear but the Aidan-Carrie storyline wasn't exactly what I wanted. And the entire point of the movie was to give us what we wanted! But with a two and a half hour run time, I can guarantee that "Sex and the City 2" will give you some of what you wanted, and a lot of stuff that you don't want.

Sex and the City 2 is a follow up to the 2008 film Sex and the City and of the long running television series of the same name. This film takes place two years after the first film with more problems facing the four women in different ways. They deal with problems at work, home, with their families/significant others and more. So when Samantha gets an all expenses paid trip to Abu Dhabi, the girls jump at the chance and that is where most of the film takes place. Before I saw the first Sex and the City film, I had not seen too much, if any of the popular television series that it followed. However, I was still interested in seeing the first film and to my great surprise, I ended up thinking what a really good film it was. I thought it's depiction of these four strong willed and independent women with their different romantic, work and other situations was handled and written quite well and after awhile I really started to care for these four characters and could see after the film why they are so drawn to one another and why they are soul mates. The first film had good writing and at times it felt very realistic to me and it added a great deal of humour and warmth to it as well. I could certainly see why the first film and the series for that matter were such big successes because after watching the first film I did watch some episodes of the television show and I enjoyed that as well. So in other words, I was quite looking forward to this second visit with the women and to see what had changed with them over the course of two years and what was going on in their fictional yet somewhat fascinating imaginary lives. This follow up film is a fun and entertaining film, but I would not go as far as to say that I enjoyed it as much as the first film, or would recommend it as highly. My few flaws with the second film are not all that much, but enough for me to give it a lower rating and not call it as much as a success as the first film, or even the show for that matter. This time I found the antics of the women and supporting characters and even the plot at times, to be a lot more silly, if almost ridiculous at times. They really loaded on the camp value in this sequel and in some films it can work quite well, but when you are trying to be serious one moment and completely over the top the next, I just don't feel it works that well, put into the same film. I also found that at times this second film did drag on a bit with it's longer running time. I was never exactly bored, but there were some scenes thrown in that I found unnecessary and did not quite understand why they were put in the film because they really served no purpose whatsoever. I also think I would have liked more on the relationships of the women in this second film as was clearly evident in the first film. A lot of the time in this sequel they are in Abu Dhabi just having fun and at times being overly juvenile and silly and the chemistry or the realism of the first film was just not there, so I found I could not connect with the characters on the same level as I did with the first film. However, besides it being over the top and not having as in depth characters, or story, I still found there was enough here for me to enjoy and to recommend it. I still found it to be quite entertaining and fun and when I purchased my ticket to see the film, that is pretty much what I expected and these were my expectations going into the film. I think if you are a fan of the first film, or the series and you are looking for more chemistry, or depth in the characters, then you may be disappointed, but if you don't mind just seeing the girls letting loose and having the time of their lives, while not quite as good, but still is fun and entertaining, then Sex and the City 2 is the right film for you.

Review title: Sex and the City 2 has no justification for its existence. Everything is just an excuse for a parade of stunning costumes, recycled jokes, and, above all, advertising
Review_body: For fans, the more they become part of their lives again, the better. Everything is an excuse to see them on the scene, with new conflicts and agendas. The result of "Sex and the City 2" is that it is still wonderful to see them together, but that there was not necessarily a need for another film for this franchise. Although there are problems with the work, the fact is that, during the 146 minutes of projection, it is impossible not to laugh at the antics they go through. While the previous feature captivates with emotion and adds acid humor, this one is only in the mood. The proposal, then, is fulfilled, even though it lacks one of the spices that made the show become a reference in the world: New York.In the two cinematic episodes of Sex and the City, the action follows the same narrative line of his life on television. The only thing really expanded is the schizophrenia of luxury, whose best example is the costumes signed by Patricia Field for each of the characters. And speaking of schizophrenia, the character of Sarah Jessica Parker plays the role that best exposes this issue, either through her clothes, or through a very confused psyche, which combines extremely unconventional and conservatism in the same figure. This time, the writers used a huge gay marriage to talk about civil liberties, and also for Liza Minnelli to star in a version of Single Ladies, hit by singer Beyoncé, in one of the funniest and most embarrassing scenes in the film. Logically, a gay marriage would not be just a place to celebrate this freedom, but all the schizophrenia of consumption and interference from the pop universe even in the most traditional of events.Much more glamor, parties, charm, travel, the best brands, breathtaking scenery, dresses to leave anyone jaw-dropping and unmissable excitement is what promises Sex and the City 2. But what happens when the film fails to present just the who gave you your greatest charisma: 'sex' and 'city'? In this new reunion of the four best New York friends, there is a little bit of everything, except the essentials. First, because three of them are very well married - and perhaps that means lack of sex, since none of them appears having sex on the scene. And the fourth - Samantha, who has always been the most liberal - spends more time complaining about her age than going into action - she even stars in two 'hot' meetings, but it is still little in the face of the girl's man-eating history.The most fascinating thing about "Sex and the City" as a whole is the fact that the public, regardless of sex or sexual option, identifies a little with each character or with the conflicts they experienced in the series and in the cinema. For this to be maintained, they return carrying the essence that marked them. Carrie remains paranoid and perhaps more boring, while Samantha continues with the best comic strips and Charlotte returns to having key moments for free during the screening. The exception is Miranda, whose sarcasm is unfortunately overshadowed, but even so her presence is essential for the balance of the friendship of the four.New York is also a character in history. In the previous feature, the streets of the cosmopolitan city were stages for broken bouquets and amorous twists, even though, from half of the projection to the end, the protagonists also left the city for a renovation trip. In this feature, little is seen of New York and this mischaracterizes what has always been ingrained. The movie's theme song, "Empire State of Mind", by Jay-Z and Alicia Keys, would be perfect if the plot unfolded major conflicts in NY. The new scenario for the story is not completely displaced, not least because cultural issues are interesting to be observed, but the least that the script could do was preserve the basics. Anyway, the trip to Abu Dhabi brings priceless comic moments, but in none of them the problems of each really move the viewer. So it is worth mentioning that this film is purely for entertainment and maybe even more fun than the first, even though this is inferior when it comes to quality.Again, screenwriter, producer and director Michael Patrick King opts for the juxtaposition of extravagant scenes, each with more dazzling costumes and more elaborate situations than the previous one. However, the plot that makes the connection between the various moments of celebration of femininity and each of the "fashion show" looks could be better tied, so that the whole made more sense. As it stands, the romantic comedy falls short and all the moments created to elicit euphoria in the women in the audience seem a little free. The film seeks to deliver to the women in its audience the escapist dream of a luxurious life, in which wonderful men and free vacations can simply fall from the sky. Sex and the City 2 is the fairy tale for the consumer society, in which a fairy godmother in the form of an Arab sheikh rescues women from the hardships of being mothers and wives to take them to the enchanted world of the Middle East, full of possibilities and mysteries.Patrick King recognizes in his script that his protagonists are no longer able to hide wrinkles, even under so much makeup, and position them as true 40s (and 50s) who thought that the stability of life would be maintained when maturity arrived. The issue is not maturity, but the fact that at any point in our lives we will have problems to resolve, and many of them involve feelings and relationships. King's script also shows exhaustion of original situations and sometimes falls into the embarrassment of others. Liza Minnelli singing "Single Ladies" is torture, as well as the extensive musical number of the protagonists singing "I Am Woman". The fashion under the cloth of Arab women is also dispensable.The mood of the text is shallow, but it is within the expiration date. Among the curiosities, a super advertisement of the actress Suzanne Somers, author of a book, among other activities, and also for the singer Paula Abdul who "wins a funny character". Ah! There is also a Brazilian flag with the inscription "I Love São Paulo" (near the end when Charlotte buys t-shirts). Stars Miley Cyrus and Penélope Cruz also make points. The soundtrack is consistent with what is seen on the screen and rescues, from 1986, "True Colors" in the voice of Cindy Lauper. Sex and the City 2 plays with the cinema by inserting in the plot, again, the faux heartthrob launched by Samantha. However, more than that, he uses a classic B&W (It Happened That Night) as a reference to illustrate Carrie's psychological conflict that he thought was living in black and white, but discovers the colors of life.In the direction, King does a little of the same, since he has never been so technical in his filming, being more urban and creative precisely when capturing the soul of New York. So he remains apathetic as a director when he takes the plot to the East. However, the filmmaker's conception of maintaining the created universe, with the brands and wide-open advertisements, as well as the incredible looks bring back the feeling that we are really seeing "Sex and the City", even though it seems like a combination of three episodes in that not everything has its deserved attention, leaving aside and discarding essential characters for the feature. Anyway, only King is able to raise the protagonists with authority and does it well.However, despite all the excesses, the sequel manages to recover from the gaffes of the first film and is not just superficial. Although little tied, the script hits the emotions and dialogues - such as, for example, a great scene between Miranda and Charlotte at the hotel bar in Abu Dhabi -, delivering a result consistent with the trajectory followed by the characters in the six years of the series. Carrie, Miranda, Samantha and Charlotte are again spherical characters, who show the best of their stereotype - the sex buff or the professional superwoman, for example -, and also rich moments when we see them totally disassembled and fragile, like any woman normal. The big budget also helps and the director takes advantage of desert locations and aerial shots in New York, providing beautiful images.Sex and the City 2 has no justification - over 146 minutes - for its existence. Everything is just an excuse for a parade of stunning costumes - and absolutely unlikely - recycled jokes, and, above all, advertising. But that does not mean that the end result is bad. Quite the opposite. It is quite impressive how well they managed to disguise the absence of a more consistent story, which really took us somewhere. The four characters are more united, and look much more like the ones we get used to seeing in the television series, contrary to what was shown in the previous film. Yes, there are great moments and sequences that are a true dream. And if everything is just an excuse to run into old and well-known friends, at least the fun is guaranteed. Sex and city may be lacking, but there is plenty of laughter, lots of sparkling wine and breathtaking events for the unsuspecting.

Carrie starts a big fight with her husband because he doesn't feel like going out to a stupid party after working into the evening. Miranda has a new boss who doesn't like her very much. Samantha is old and needs to take hormones for menopause. From an artistic standpoint, there were some plot elements and character developments I didn't think were totally needed. They do however drive the story, which seemed to be their purpose, so I can accept them. Heartfelt and riveting from the first frame to the last. Great performances help to enhance this amazing story of a friendship. The kind of film that proves that a small story can be much more meaningful than a larger one.

A new installment in the SACT franchise, with all the elements that the fans of the series loved. The new episode focus on how our favorite four girls face the challenges of marriage and consolidated relationships, and how marriage means different things for different people.I'm surprised at the poor reviews of this movie, which I think it is not worse than the first, which has double rating. Completely senseless. The story has moments of the soul of the TV and Carrie's character. Needless to say, fashion and luxury are still gorgeous and an essential part of the look and mood of the movie, but the story makes good points and grounds the characters. Most importantly, the acting has returned to what we were used in the TV series, making us forget some of the flaws we resented in the first movie. I cannot believe that nobody noticed how terrible was in the first, and that is back to normal here.The movie has some very fun moments, many of them by the always cheeky (and hilariously vulgar) Samantha. The gay wedding at the beginning is great, with a cameo by Liza Minelli as wedding minister and wedding singer.I think the main problem of the movie is the whole trip to Abu Dhabi. Not the trip, the destination. I had the feeling that this was a long commercial about Abu Dhabi. The girls could have gone elsewhere luxurious and still face the same challenges. I thought that focusing on cultural differences and the idiosyncrasy of the Emiraties was a waste of time, and completely unnecessary for the story, which, until the trip starts, was making good points about marriage. In short, I would have eliminated the touristy part and dug deep in the part of the relationships. On the other hand, this being a show about sex, love and relationships by very liberated Western Women, the UAE were never going to be a good destination. Never ever! This is one of those chick-flicks that will entertaining women who were fans of the TV series and have all the background to understand and enjoy the characters and what is happening in this double length episode, which is what it really is.Abstain from viewing men and people who are not familiar with the series. Otherwise, don't complain!

Review title: What a horrible piece of celluloid or digital capture
Review_body: I should have copied and pasted this review from somebody else who bashed it, because I already wrote too many reviews today and to write one for another crap movie just made it all the harder.I believe that I watched 3 TV shows of this and they had really offered little to no entertainment to me and this did even less.To see this on silkscreen is like watching a 2 hour tampon commercial shot in New York City and in Dubai with a larger cast and a larger budget.It's boring, bland and just dreadful to see this on a large screen when I can watch a 30 second commercial of a tampon commercial or makeup cosmetic commercial and have it over much more quickly.Blahhhhhhhhh....Yukkkkkkkkkkkk...crap extended and what makes this worse is that I even sat through it instead of going back home and going to sleep.

Review title: Crass and crude: would we have it any other way?
Review_body: I've always thought that the quartet of 'ladies' in Sex and the City are really meant to be four gay men played by actresses. It's harder to hold this view now that three of them are married and two of them are mothers. But Samantha, still single (and a slut) at 52, is more like several gay men I've known than any woman of my acquaintance (perhaps I move in the wrong circles).Playing to the gay audience, we have the cringe-inducing 'marriage' between Carrie's best gay friend and Charlotte's best gay friend (Martha and Martha!). Ageing icon Liza Minelli improbably officiates at this ceremony and then provides the (pardon the pun) cabaret. She talks and sings as if her mouth is full of pebbles. Joan Rivers needs to give Liza some career advice ("Liza, it's over").Half the movie takes place in Abu Dhabi on a PR junket of Samantha's. There are modesty jokes galore (and a few 'daring' burka gags) and Samantha (surprise!) has one or two immodest moments.The critics have generally dismissed this, as well they might. Yes, it's crass and crude, but when wasn't it? There's some full-on sex (guess who? no prizes), a lot of full-on smut and an endless fashion parade of silly frocks, but hey, what else do we expect? The barrel is very close to being scraped dry. Maybe they should let ten years go by and then revisit them in their 50s and 60s, perhaps living in Florida, all divorced - it could be a raunchier version of The Golden Girls. David Gee is available (and very affordable) for script-writing!

From the television to the big screen, the girls of Sex and the City are back. Filled with fashion, shoes and lots of sex, the girls realize life's realities of keeping the magic alive. As an escape of the daily grind the girls travel Abu Dabi to rediscover the good life and be renewed. The packed screening has jeers and cheers that these herorines fight throw the issues of the modern woman. The highlight of the film was Liza Minnelia making a cameo playing her self performing "All the Single Ladies" from the Beyonce chart winning number one hit. Catch up to what is happening from the dynamic four cool cats from the big apple.
Costume + Music : 6Setting and some beautiful scenes : 1Cheesy Ending : -1

Review title: Calm down it's just eye candy
Review_body:
I don't know why everyone in this comment section is so mad: this movie is clearly and unabashedly just eye candy. The setting, the plot, the dresses... everything is accurately built just to show you some luxury stuff.
The plot and most of the characters are incredibly stupid but that's the point: you can focus on the visual and that's that.
This movie is only one time watch and time pass i think movie is so amazing but not its little comedy and little nude in this

Review title: Ruined the legacy of the series.
Review_body: Should have left well enough alone, but the greed got to them. This movie is absolutely pointless and downright embarrassing, let alone as a sequel to the series. Just stop.

Review title: What on earth happened to the girls?
Review_body: Seriously, was there anything else to add after the end of the first film? Absolutely not. But they did it any way, and the result was absolutely devastating, sick and plain unnecessary.All the women do in this film is complain, day and night about their "horrible", "miserable" and "unfulfilled" bloody lives. They literally have absolutely every thing they ever wanted and more, and they still aren't satisfied. Charlotte always wanted a baby of her own, and now that she has one, she locks herself in the closet and cries just because she can't control her, and fretting over her nanny's breasts. Carrie turns into a nagging bitch wife unhappy with the takeaway food and flat screen TV in the bedroom her husband gave her. Samantha's gobbling down pills so she doesn't have to deal with menopause, and she's also being unfaithful to her boyfriend, who stuck by her through Chemo, even though she was faithful to him in the first film. Miranda, despite working at her firm for God knows how long, suddenly is belittled by a male colleague, and she quits. And Stanford, Carrie's gay friend, is all of a sudden in love with his enemy Anthony, and they marry! And Liza Minelli shows up to perform at their wedding, performing a slightly tone deaf version of "Single Ladies".And it just gets worse. After Samantha impresses an Arabic partner, they are all being treated to the luxury of luxuries in a palace in Abu Dhabi, which they really don't deserve. Despite having to leave early after Samantha disrespects the Muslim culture with her outgoing sexuality, they still get to fly first class back home. What a joke.These b--ches want it all and they get it but it's still not enough for them. The script has to be the worst I've ever seen on screen. There were so many silly things simply put in there such as the Muslim women wearing designer clothes under their mosque clothing, and even the Aiden plot seemed unnecessary in the end (although I did like seeing him)It wasn't even funny. Every "unfulfilled" part of their lives is filled up in the end. Oh so happy! Happy, happy, happy! Maybe in a fantasy world, but not in the real one.

Like 90% of the world, I was a huge fan of the show, even when there was some awful seasons and very awful episodes that were making clear that the show was losing its essence and becoming what people were always talking about and expecting making it more of a nonsense fashion show than any other thing.OK, until then, it worked well on TV while there was a background story.4 years later the end of the series the first movie arrived and it was cool because see the girls together seemed to be never enough and it was fun and loose and better than my expectations.When S&TC2 was being planned, I asked myself what more Carrie would have to say? The lack of ideas reflected on the reviews that - fair enough - rated the movie one of the worst titles of 2010.There's a moment in the movie that defines its entire 146 minutes when Carrie reads a review of her newest book which says that "she would be better advised to explore the value of silence" and a cartoon with a cross-tape in her mouth is shown. That moment happens a little too late when the movie is absolutely boring with nothing more interesting to add. While Darren Starr wrote it for Carrie, it fits perfect for Darren himself because there's no reason for the existence of S&TC anymore. It's paradoxical the fact that someone as Carrie became famous writing about the single life and the search of the love happiness and now became just another old and bold housewife.The movie is awful since its opening credits with letters using diamond and sparkling textures, an outrageous gay marriage, Liza Minelli singing and dancing Beyonce's Single Ladies in a appearance that she should had avoid for the sake of her career and 4 gals walking on the desert like on a runway using horrible clothes that not even the richest fashionist woman in the world would have the dignity to use.Everything in the movie is exacerbated to a shameful level. It's impossible to watch. Poor dialogs, infamous moments and 4 actresses that seems to don't know what they're doing and where they are going.Sex And The City is now old and bold as Carrie Bradshaw became. It's no secret that it's time to let them go and stop trying to destroy the best of them that still in our memories.

Could there be a worse movie for the times we are in. The country is in a recession, many people are out of work and the best these people can come up with is a trashy flick about a bunch of spoiled rich women who cry and whine constantly even though they have everything in the world. Carrie has the man she loves, lives in a multi-million dollar NYC apartment that she would not have if it weren't for him plus she has another expensive apartment but all she does is complain that he wants to relax and watch a movie because she hasn't been out for an exciting night in what....a day or two? Who would listen to this crap and pamper this woman? And could they please stop trying to fool anyone into believing she is anything but ugly.Then you have a woman making $200K a year who quits her job because her boss is mean and we are supposed to feel sorry for her? I am a man and part of any appeal of the TV version was that you got to see sex and the jokes were OK, but the older these women get the less anyone cares about their issues. Samantha's character is just gross at this point, what was that disgusting thing she did in her office? Ewww. Why would young model type men want with this old bag? I have no sympathy for these people, I don't care what happens to them.And now these poor women have to fly on the richest airline to a super rich place, oh my what are they to do??? Could anything be more silly then that hat Carrie is wearing to get on an airplane? Way to save the environment, their own private plane for 4 people and they each get their own 300K car.The desert scene with the camels has to be some of the worst film making in history and asks the age old question, what the hell are they wearing? Did the camels pick out the clothes? The ending is ludicrous with Arab women wearing heavy designer clothes under burqas in 100 degree heat.

This movie was unnecessary once again. I get it. These characters are fun characters and people like watching them interact but i just once again feel like there was nothing to be said once again.The glaring issue is this movie is also too long. 2 and a half hours! That is 5 times the run time of a single episode of the original series. That is a big jump and i don't think it works especially when then story isn't there to support the long run time.I actually found this movie slightly funnier than the previous but only by a slight margin. But i just couldn't get past the blah-ness.Kim Cattrall is great as always but why she is also great is she's the only thing stopping them making a third movie, so good on her. They would keep making them because like i said people love these characters, i do too but i don't want to see them just like flounder around the screen not growing or developing. I said it in the last review that these characters have plateaued. They have reached their end and big surprise they ended once again where we started with them.I do want to mention the start of this movie because it was the strangest thing id seen all week, Liza Minelli singing Single Ladies. That maybe even be enough to make the film watchable.

Review title: I Really Don't Understand All The Hate...
Review_body: Having read the many AWFUL reviews, and seeing the VERY low rating (4.9 at the time), I expected the worst.I was sitting there expecting to get insulted/bored/disappointed/outraged (amongst many of the awful things this movie has been called), but nothing of the sort ever happened.A lot of people seem to complain that the movie is "insulting" to the culture of the Middle East... I didn't see anything remotely insulting. Lots of movies, involving a foreign culture, will use stereotypes to portray it. This is something the viewers can understand and relate to. What's the point showing hidden traditions of a particular culture and portraying it in a different light than that known to your average viewer?? For God's sake, people, if you want an accurate/multi-dimensional portrayal of a culture, watch a DOCUMENTARY. This is fiction, and the movie has a purpose - to entertain the viewer, therefore - it's SUPPOSED to be exaggerated and stereotypical.Another popular complaint, is that these girls are not the same as in the sitcom. Hello?? And what exactly did you expect? It's been, what, OVER 1O YEARS?? Do you think these girls are going to be exactly the same as they were in the sitcom? How dumb is that? Their lives have changed (and so have their views), they have grown older, and some of them have kids -- the movie reflects these changes; it's only natural. The girls COULDN'T have remained the same!! Well, I have to say, I have never been too fond of Charlotte (not the character itself, but Kristen Davies's portrayal; more specifically: her constant OVER-acting), and she has really crossed the line in this one. Her acting was bad in the first movie, but, in this one, it's bordering on unbearable. And I didn't like that ridiculous "Irish bra-less lesbian babysitter" story, either. It was just stupid and totally over-the-top.Miranda's character was severely under-developed, and so was the story with Aidan. And, to be honest, the Carrie and Big story was a bit cheesy for my liking. I mean, fighting over the fact that a man wants to watch a little TV after work? Please! All in all, the movie was pretty well put together, and, in my opinion, the things people are complaining about, are absolutely irrelevant. The movie is FINE -- it's entertaining, there are some great clothes, and we get to see lots of familiar faces. Never a dull moment! I was not disappointed at all.

I guess that this is what happens after the prince and Cinderella shut the castle gates - happily ever after (not). The problem is that Cinderella (Carrie) is a spoiled little madam, not only did she blame Big for everything that went wrong during their courtship and then the disastrous wedding for which she was to blame - they had agreed on a quiet wedding and she went ballistic with Vogue and a Vivienne Westwood gown - but then, after two years of living in paradise with a gorgeous man who adores her and lavishes all he can on her in the way of worldly goods and attention, she has a tantrum because he is selfish enough to buy her a state of the art TV for their bedroom so that, after a day's graft of earning the money to keep her in luxury, he can relax. How dare he! Switch then to another storyline with Samantha, who hit 50 in the last film, so technically should be through menopause by now, but no, is taking every pill and lotion under the sky to ward off symptoms and acting like an out of control pantomime dame, and Miranda who has a new boss who doesn't like her, and of course Charlotte, whose children have a nanny who doesn't wear a bra but who loves to draw attention to that fact - well of course, all meaningful crises in the normal world, but we are talking megabucks city here guys. Then by some chance they are whisked away to the United Arab Emirates, to Abu Dahbi, where the luxury is excessive even to one who dreams of winning lotto. There, bare skinned and offensively dressed and behaving badly they proceed to upset the locals and get kicked out, after Carrie has met up with old flame Aiden and kissed him and phoned Big to blurt out the truth - why not wait until you can do this humanely, face to face if you have to tell him, and if it meant nothing, why torment the poor chap? They arrive home, having learned that of course all Arab women wear NY fashions under their black costumes and read trashy NY books. Big's punishment for Carrie is to give her a massive diamond. Embarrassing to see Samantha, (my favourite) become a joke; sad to see Miranda, (my second favourite) and Charlotte so petty, and sad to see that Carrie (sorry but always watched despite her, not because of her) has not grown up yet and is still childish, sulky, spoiled and ridiculous. A real disappointment. Quit while you can girls...

Boy, were the reviews and ratings wrong on this one. I get busy in spring and do my gardening thing so just made it to see SATC2. I'm sooo glad my daughters (baby-boomers) and I went to the theater to see the girls in their outrageous clothes, deal with their silly problems and get on that plane. What a plane - showing the individual 'pods' the upscale tickets gets you. What a dream! Then we get to that great hotel, and are given a tour along with our girls. Great! And a one day desert outing. Oh yeah! Great locations. Cinematography is wonderful! Story? Smart, rich women have the same kind of silly problems with their lives all the rest of us do. You can either make a movie and laugh; or make a tragedy and cry. We can cry just living our own lives. Carrie, Samantha et al, over the top, and making us laugh - is what this group of 'women' want. 8/10

*small spoilers*As a huge fan of the series, I was generally happy with the first movie. However, in true Hollywood fashion, the dead horse continues to get beaten. We get the concept here, as we have for 12 years: Charlotte is the pampered stay-at-home mom and wife who apparently "needs a break". A break? From what? She has a full-time nanny! Anyways, I digress. Samantha is the usual sex fiend who can't keep her zipper closed for more than a day at a time. Miranda is the overly-feminist lawyer/mom who tries to balance life and work (again, as we've seen for 12 years) and Carrie just can't decide if she wants to be the single party gal or a married woman. I understand the need to break away and find solace to do her writing. As a writer myself, I can see that. But then she turns a suggestion of Big's to stay in, wear sweats and watch TV into a threat to her Prada/Gucci-filled go-out-every-night lifestyle. The movie is filled with the usual lame one-liners. "Lawrence of my labia?" Samantha, are you serious? After the dreadful and completely pointless gay wedding, we're whisked off to the mid east where Carrie can't stay faithful for a week and Charlotte turns into a bumbling nitwit in search of cheezy trinkets for her kids. When they were running through the streets incognito and discover a group of women who wear designer clothes under their robes/gowns (yeah, right) my stomach churned with agony. We get the characters and the storyline already and nothing ever really changes. An amazing show turned into a sequel with a plot so painfully replayed I truly hope they put SATC to bed already (no pun intended).

Review title: Time to hang up the Manolo's?
Review_body: I love the Sex in the City girls and it's great to spend time with them now and again. The first film outing of the TV series was okay, but not great, so a 2nd? Well, yes I paid money to see this at the cinema and really it could have waited for DVD-it's perfect fodder for a Sunday afternoon- but I'm not sure whether they should have bothered.Times have changed, the girls are older, more settled and I'm not sure I like them like that. I think I prefer them younger and more frivolous. It didn't seem right to see Carrie fretting about furniture. At 2 and half hours this is way too long and whilst the budget is bigger, the story is light and not very exciting. In fact nothing really happens and what does is overly predictable and some a little cheesy - the girls singing 'I am Woman' at karaoke made me cringe, as did the 'gag' of the girls wearing burka's at the end.There are some things to enjoy: there are still some amazing clothes (although, some of the outfits they wore whilst visiting Abu Dhabi, seemed stupidly over the top: the outfit Carrie wears to the souk was outrageous). There is plenty of gayness: in fact Liza Minelli singing and dancing to Beyonce's 'Single Ladies' at a gay wedding that also has a gay mens chorus and white swans may be the gayest thing ever on film. But despite this there is something lacking. It feels flat and rather flaccid compared to the TV series. The sex talk has gone, the sex scenes and flesh are very tame and there isn't the cracking one liners (it is Samantha who has the best declaring a new man will be her 'Lawrence of her labia'). But there isn't as much fun in it and some of it bordered on cheap gags-the nanny and her bouncing bossum for instance, it's not Benny Hill...this and much else seemed way beyond something Sex would have done in it's original format.It's also a shame that they felt they had to drag all the characters into this, Aiden being in Abu Dhabi as well, just seemed too convenient, but then if that had happened, there really wouldn't have been much else to the story. I'm not sure they should hang their Manolo's up, but they should certainly consider changing into something a little more comfortable.More of my reviews at my site: iheartfilms.weebly.com

Urrrrgh, they're back in the ineviatable sequel, but now they go to Abu Dhabi! Pretty much the same thing as "Sex 1", but with a new location. The girls still carry on the same way while they giggle,talk about dreams, reality,goals, meeting perfect men, clothes, shoes, etc, etc, etc. There is also a performance by Chris Noth as Mr. Big {anybody care to guess why he is called that?} and he talks about the caste system, justice, social issues and the two kinds of people in the world. Obviously this guy never took a real philosophy class! There was a gay wedding where has-been Liza Minelli sings that just fell flat-not to mention it featuring every gay stereotype that can be imagined. To call this movie long is missing the point. You don't actually watch it, you endure it. There are scenes of the girls in the desert that feature the fakest looking rear projection that you've ever seen. Some of the visuals do look pretty good, but that ain't saying too much. As in Sex 1, this is the kind of movie that men get dragged to and have to admit they enjoyed it to please their dates. Again, I really can enjoy a good womans picture just as much as the next guy, but this one just ain't it. The estrogen level is so high, you can fuel a 747 with it and fly it around the world. Also, as in the first one, there are so many product placements in this film that I just couldn't count 'em all. Not really a movie in the conventional sense, its just a super expanded and padded out TV show, and a paper thin one at that. The Abu Dhabi locations are exotic looking, but , like the women themselves ,they just serve as a backdrop to hang the story on. It could have been set anywhere on Earth and the results would still be the same. Maybe I am being somewhat hard on it, but lets face it. The movies that play the multiplexes today are just products. They have no heart, soul or real worth. Everything is just the same old recycled product . Prequels, sequels, re-makes, franchises, comic book heroes and TV into movies like this. ATTENTION -Men! If you get duped into seeing this avenge yourself! Look for a revival theater , find a movie like "Great Escape", "Apocalypse Now", "The Longest Day", "Patton" or any real man movie and drag your date to go see that! Its called "payback" and its a bit-h .... you know that. This is probably the ultimate movie for the dumbed down multiplex era of lowered expectations. My rating-one star. Unless you are a Masochist, avoid it like the plague! You've been warned. Another PU movie review from Lou.

I have a review of the first Sex and the City movie on this site, so if you are interested in what I wrote, I invite you to read my review. Now as for this, the second, Sex and the City, movie, well, my review is just about the same, in that I really enjoyed it. I think it is simply fabulous entertainment---NOT to be taken too seriously, but just to be enjoyed. It follows the lives of the four women two years later. Miranda is having a problem with her new boss; Charlotte is finding motherhood somewhat of a challenge; Samantha's mind is competing with her aging body; and Carrie is not exactly thrilled that married life to Mr. Big is not the social whirlwind she may have envisioned for herself. Stanford gets married in a lavish gay wedding, complete with Liza Minelli, who looks older, thinner, who seemed very,very strained in her voice and in her speech--something was amiss with her speaking voice. The plot in the first movie was more of a drama; this movie is not as intense as the first movie, but more of a comedy--that is how I would classify it. That is really the big difference between the two films. All, with the exception of the slim downed Kim Cattrall, do look a wee but older, or as someone else said, the photography of the women is not the best in this sequel. Kim, as I said, lost a lot of weight, and looks great. Carrie's hair is a bit darker, so, perhaps, that is why she looks drawn. The girls have an adventure in the UAR, and the whole plot is unrealistic and very, very far fetched--as if anything like this could possibly happen to someone in REAL life, but, again, this is a movie. A lot of the reviewers here are taking the whole thing just too seriously. I found it a funny, touching and just a great movie. I could see it again and again. You should too.

Once upon a time, there were four fabulous ladies from New York City who charms the world with fashion, love and sex. Thus, Sex and the City was born.In 2008, the girls had a reunion on the big screen, and it puts to an perfect ending to the series.However, in 2010, another reunion on the big screen was created, which this time round, the reunion does not seems to be enjoyable compared to the previous reunion, which brings love, trust, faith, hope and ever lasting friendship together.Welcome to Sex and the City 2, which brings fails to deliver the high expectation from fans of the popular HBO series. Love and sex remains, together with more exaggerating comical sequences, posh nosh and time consuming plot, which not only bores and sometimes frustrates audience, but also, a disappointment to the fans of Sex and the City.Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker), Miranda (Cynthia Nixon), Charlotte (Kristin Davis) and Samantha (Kim Cattral) are back together on the sequel, which begins with a list of problems they are facing in their daily life: Carrie is in doubt with Big (Chris Noth) on their marriage; Miranda faces the pressure of a chauvinistic boss; Charlotte unable to handle her two daughters growing up together, and Samantha is tackling menopause. An unexpected invitation to a holiday at Abu Dhabi for th girls allows them to enjoy themselves, and at the same time, clearing about their thoughts on their love life and marriage.Sex and the City 2 promises to be another fashion parade. However, girls don themselves with clothing unsuitable for the weather and environment in Abu Dhabi pulls the movie down, since it makes the girls looks lavish and filthy rich, rather than stylish and chic. While the latest fashion fits in perfectly in New York City, the crew has failed to consider creating clothing that fits into the environment and culture of Abu Dhabi. Thus, it does not bring out the charm the girls ought to get from wearing them, which has been displayed in the previous series.The plot seems like a typical episode of Sex and the City, but such typical plot are good for the drama series rather than the movie. The paper thin plot can be seen as a form of extension from one of the episodes, which looks rather dull and draggy. Sub plots were added in to keep the movie going, which fails to point out some of the points that can be discussed further in the movie. Instead of keeping the spirit of Sex and the City going strong, the second half of the Sex and the City 2 seems to be a farce.Discussion of culture and religion in Abu Dhabi has also diverted the spirit of the series away, which at some point, could be offensive and uncomfortable to some audience who are not prepared for it. For fans, this might be seen as a sequence that has no relation to the girl's usual talk over the coffee table.The strong support for each other and the friendship is the only saving grace for the movie, which not only ends haphazardly, but also fails to end with a big bang.In summary, director Michael Patrick King and Parker can do more to salvage Sex and the City 2. Remedy must be done to save this broken pieces of anticipated reunion in order to keep the spirits alive.

When it comes to movies like this, I think of it as a typical Sex & the City episode, lots of innuendos and pretty clothing and the Carrie Bradshaw over voice narration. And that's what it was: just entertaining day. This movie is better than the first. I might say that just because I actually went into the theater and watched it.Then the last 20 minutes got really silly, and a bit disrespectful towards the end, outrageous and lacking the foremost entertainment. And I never like what Carrie wears it's just ugly.Overall watch it if you have love for Sex & the City the TV series, and don't expect too much from the movie and you won't be disappointed.

Review title: If you thought the first movie was bad, it's nothing compared to the second movie!
Review_body: So I've seen Sex and the City: The Movie and I thought it was below average (4/10) but does the second one improve from the first movie's flaws? No, it doesn't! If anything, it's added more flaws. The story was very basic and not in a good way, it was boring and not interesting in the slightest. The girls basically moaned about their lives so Samantha manages to bag the women a holiday to Abu Dhabi where they moaned even more (except for a couple of scenes). The characters were poorly written this time round as all of them did nothing but nag, moan and bitch about everything in their lives. If they weren't bitching to their families, the women would get together over lunch and have a good bitch at their lives. The acting was so-so, there were a couple of okay moments when the actresses didn't do a bad job but there were a lot of moments when it was bad. The direction is rubbish, the writing is a joke and the script isn't fun at all.Sex and the City 2 tries to be something it's not: Fun, sexy and smart. The worst thing about the movie is, yet again, the runtime. Two and a half hours is simply too long for this movie and the plot was very thin. I could have very easily cut sixty minutes out of the movie and you wouldn't miss anything. The only reason why I saw this was because I saw the first and I very stupidly thought that it could improve, but it didn't. Another thing that bugged me was the stuff they were wearing. This movie is supposed to be all about glamorous fashion and things but half the stuff they were wearing looked horrible, I couldn't see any woman with a sane mind wearing half the stuff they displayed in the movie. The characters were yet again stereotypical but this time, it was more blatant and in-your-face. The acting wasn't very good at all, they did a better job in the first movie. The 'funny' scenes aren't funny at all, except for the parts with Erin the Irish Nanny who made Samantha jealous. Overall, one of the worst movies this year and possibly one of the worst chick flicks I have ever seen and in even worse news, if the rumours are true, it's possible that it could be a trilogy! God help the world of cinema! Read more reviews at: www.dudedazzmoviereviews.wordpress.com
First of all, I'm a big sex and the city fan. I can't believe the 4.5 score for this movie, I think if you are a fan you will love this movie. It's a true joy to watch. Funny like always.

Review title: Worse than I ever could have imagined.
Review_body: This could be the worst movie ever made. Certainly its the worst I've seen in a very long time. Now, before I begin I have to say that I'm not a fan of the series to begin with. It had its moments, but as a lifelong resident of Manhattan I mostly blamed the series for the unbearable influx of wide-eyed moronic girls from all over the country who flocked to the city en masse, thinking that upon arrival their lives would instantly revolve around cosmopolitans, rich men and $1000 shoes, and who very quickly became insufferable basket cases once the reality of city life actually set in on them. Of course, I saw this movie with my girlfriend, as my good deed for the week. What I was not prepared for was how horrible it actually was. The first ten minutes contained more cliché, stinted dialog, corny jokes and general awkwardness than I had previously thought possible in such a short time frame. It was embarrassing. It also involved Liza Minelli. I thought it couldn't get worse, but oh did it ever. Next came the foundation for the entire film, which was that the ladies were in a funk and needed to get away for a couple of weeks. The funny thing about that is how they all have impossibly great lives, especially by NYC standards. They live in massive apartments, have high-paying careers, plenty of money and for everyone but Samantha, loving husbands and families. And its not like there was some substantial existential crisis underpinning their dissatisfaction to legitimize their feelings and generate sympathy on behalf of the audience. It all amounted to 'Boohoooo we used to partyyyy all the time but now we're all grownups waaa pity us'. Literally, that was it. Sorry, I don't feel bad for you guys. So Carrie starts a whole big fight with her husband because he doesn't feel like going out to some stupid party after working into the evening and providing her with a lifestyle that includes what appears to be a $15 million apartment, two luxury cars, an unlimited decorating budget, a truly massive closet with hundreds of thousands of dollars in clothes, enough leisure time to write her stupid books AND her old apartment to write them in. Then he had the NERVE to not buy her jewelry for their anniversary (she actually said that). It was completely effing nauseating.The rest of the women's 'problems' were no better. Charlotte has kids who drive her crazy. Really groundbreaking stuff there. Especially since she too lives in a multimillion dollar apartment with a full time live-in nanny and housekeeper. Pathetic. Miranda has a new boss who doesn't like her very much, OBVIOUSLY because she's a woman, duh. There's no other reason for a boss to not like a subordinate other than their gender, clearly. And finally, Samantha is old and needs to take hormones for menopause now, stop the presses. Is your heart bleeding for them yet? No? You must hate women, you sexist. Moving right along. Samantha somehow is a mega-PR agent at this point (in Times Square??), despite the fact that I've literally never seen her do any work resembling PR (and I know lots of PR people). She meets some sheik at a party who simply MUST have her work that imaginary PR magic on behalf of his new hotel, and as a perk of this great new account, conveniently gets the girls invited to Abu Dhabi. Hooray! Their dreary despair comes to an end as they're flown ultra-first-class to the glamorous 'new' middle-east, shuttled to the luxury hotel in individual Maybach limousines (one for each of them!) and given two weeks all-expenses-paid in the hotel's premier $22,000/night penthouse suite, because that is totally standard treatment for PR flacks. Naturally. All is well in this paradise for like a week, until the icky middle-eastern customs of female oppression begin to rear their ugly head and Samantha is inevitably arrested for being a giant whore and having sex on the beach with some Dutch dude, at which point they're politely informed that Samantha's PR expertise would not be needed after all, and that they'd be personally responsible for another night of hotel charges unless they vacated the hotel in one hour. So now these four extremely wealthy women proceed to freak the hell out because if they don't hurry they may be liable for (gasp!) $5,500 each to cover the suite. Makes perfect sense to me too. Never mind that they're millionaires, particularly Carrie, whose couch alone in her living room is worth upwards of $30,000. Never mind that they could have also asked to be moved into regular rooms for the night so they could leave at a normal pace the next day. But on the other hand, if they had been logical, we wouldn't have been treated to a madcap scene of the girls packing and then inexplicably getting into trouble at the local bazaar (again related to Samantha's inability to keep her clothes on), followed by a quasi-insulting scene of burqa-clad women revealing designer clothes under their robes and reading a Susanne Sommers menopause book, for some reason. Ultimately they make their way to the airport in a horrible little gypsy cab (because between the four of them they couldn't afford a limo of their own too?), and before you know it, they're off to America again. Oh and Carrie hooked up with her ex boyfriend at some point in there and told her husband about it for no good reason. Predictably, they get home and everyone is as introspective as they're capable of (not very much at all), and they realize how wonderful their lives really are (no they don't). The end.Now you don't need to see the movie. You're welcome.

A lot of people exercise their brains with puzzles found in the newspaper. Sudoku is a prime example. The variety published by a typical paper can usually be solved in less than 5 minutes, or at least that's been my experience with them. The goal for me was to grab an issue of The Kansan, take a seat in class, and have the Sudoku finished before learning was to commence. I didn't have class every day, so when I didn't need the Sudoku I kept the paper. A small pile sits next to me as I type this review. I never got to working a single puzzle after graduating; I found that writing and talking about movies was a more suitable exercise for me. It seems that the worse the movie in question, the more mistakes there are to find. For that reason alone, Sex and the City 2 is a good brain teaser.The adventure begins when Carrie Preston (Sarah Jessica Parker) and friends Miranda (Cynthia Nixon), Charlotte (Kristin Davis), and Samantha (Kim Cattrall) attending the wedding of their best gay friends. Since this is based on a long running TV series, I'm sure fans of the show found more significance to the scene than I did. In my eyes it was the most logical way to present Liza Minnelli as herself singing Beyoncé's "Single Ladies". It's a scene that can't be unseen, and I knew instantly that it would haunt me for the rest of the summer. Everyone at the wedding makes Carrie feel bored with her life now that she's settled down with Mr. Big (Chris Noth). The most bizarre way this is accomplished is by having a random couple tell them they will be lonely if they don't have children. Then wouldn't you know it, something ridiculous happens and the girls get flown to Abu Dhabi where they are treated like royalty all because some sheik wants Samantha work a PR campaign for his property. But don't worry, our leading ladies forget about any logical objective and proceed to flaunt what they got in the desert.I realize this movie didn't have me in mind when it was created. This is my first experience with the girls of Sex and the City and from what I gathered I can see why an hour-long TV program running on premium cable would be a hit. These girls are rude, and vulgar, but they play off of each other like champs. When they are seated at a table gossiping is when Sex and the City 2 shows any hint of a shine. The problems then smudge that polish.I've never seen so many costume changes. I'm convinced it's the driving point behind the narrative. Every scene is constructed to show what Carrie and the girls can put on then lead to another situation for them to dress up. No movie should be so shallow, and even worse they look flammable and toxic. I wasn't sure if the running gag is that Carrie doesn't know she looks like a low rent streetwalker, there's a sign of trouble if ever there was one.No care is shown with the characters. Samantha sleeps with absolutely any guy regardless of the situation, and the outcome is too much to stomach. Miranda has a subplot about needing to balance work and family which gets lost in a sea of plunging necklines. Charlotte frets about her husband cheating on her with their nanny every 10 minutes. Lastly, Carrie is simply too selfish to be likable. She has a husband who seems to be doing a fantastic job by everyone else's standards. To her, he needs to do more and this sets her up for a lamebrain, and oddly predictable, encounter with an old flame.The wanton excess of this movie leaves no doubt as to why the world hates us. Sex and the City 2 is a better terrorist motivational tool than it is an enjoyable time at the theatre. These girls are easily living the life in New York before the film takes its sweet time to send them to the Middle East where everything is ratcheted up to 11. They each get a personal Maybach 62 S so they can be chaffered to and from locations where they can offend locals and change clothes. There's an occasionally clever line but that won't vindicate watching it.

Review title: First part OK, last 45 minutes unwatchable
Review_body: When I started this movie, I was thinking "hey, this isn't so bad -- why all the hate?" It was nice seeing the ladies again, and even though the dialogue was pretty cheesy, I was actually enjoying it. BUT by the last 45 minutes, I was ready to just turn it off. Around the time that Samantha got arrested, the plot just got so absurd that I wasn't sure if I could make it through the end. It became too stupid and NOTHING like the actual show. Granted, it wasn't a great movie before that point, just mediocre, but it was certainly watchable, especially if you were a fan of and miss SATC.I think it's time to say good-bye to the girls. There's no reason another movie needs to be made.

Review title: Maybe I was in a good mood that day?
Review_body: I read the horrible reviews before I saw the movie, but I was still hyped about going to see it with my friend. We saw it, we laughed, we ooed and awed at the scenery, the extravagance, etc. and we accepted it for what it was. In my opinion, this movie was consistent with both the series and the first movie. These are not exercises in Oscar nods or deep, dramatic story lines. The whole crux of this book/series is lighthearted exploration of relationship and fashion. That's what this movie offered. And as someone who was wondering how the writers would broach this movie given that the main storyline of the series and first movie--Carrie chasing Big--was pretty much sowed up, how would the married Carrie be a relatable protagonist for the single-girl audience? I think they pulled it off pretty well. The dissension between Carrie and Big was real and relatable. As was the frustration of Charlotte being a new mother. So again, for what it is, the genre it is, it is a decent offering. I really don't understand why someone who enjoyed the series would not enjoy this movie. In my opinion, it's virtually the same.Virtually.I will concede that the plot in this movie was lacking, was not fleshed through well. The Carrie-Aiden moment was just dropped off clip with no real resolution. And none of the others really faced dilemmas. It was light--maybe too light. It could have used a little bit of real drama, like the first movie. It could have used just a tad bit more seriousness. That I will concede.But again, if you are a fan of the series and the original movie, you should at least semi-enjoy this movie because it's not really that far off. It is just like a prolonged episode of the series. Maybe not the best episode, but one that at least entertains for a spell.See it if you liked the series. Skip it if you are "above" this genre of film. 6.5/10P.S. The only thing that I will add as maybe a negative (or not) is that the extravagance is way over-the-top, to the point that you find yourself alternating between longing for that kind of life and shaking your head at the unrealistic-ness of it all.

Review title: Everything you thought it would be - and more
Review_body: I guess it was obvious from the very beginning that the sequel to Sex and the City wouldn't become critics' favorite; but it's not that type of movie that yearns their acceptance. It's not as much about deeper meanings, as it is about having fun, letting your imagination go wild, along with your inhibitions.And as far as the fun part is concerned, SATC2 is a blast. It's pretty much SATC, but bigger, better, louder and shinier.Not that it doesn't have flaws. The product placement is, as always, very annoying. The storyline is a bit too much sometimes, and it seems like the story gets out of hand more than once or twice. Carrie's inner monologues have lost their wit and smarts, even though she still delivers great lines when faced with other people. Samantha is her usual self, the one that she's always been. But it's Miranda's and Charlotte's characters that steal the show. Miranda was finally given a chance to sparkle, be fun and brave, something that's been missing in the first part. Davis' performance is extraordinary, and it really shows when York is facing real emotional problems with her family.Overall, it's a gay fantasy - it's bold, sparkling and bigger than life. It's not a cinematographic masterpiece, but it's a whole lot of fun.

At the very least they should have been able to exert some control, direction and/or changes to this train wreck.Breakdown of the women: narcissistic, whiny, dumb, ignorant, self-absorbed, classless, boring, shallow, weak, drama queens, embarrassing, old, needy and in need of mega therapy.I'm going to agree with other posters who said that SJP is Ugly...no hating here...just burned corneas from staring at the screen in disbelief and realization that there must have been some soft focus lenses getting daily use of the series set.These women need to eat also - it was very distracting to watch them move with sinewy muscle and protruding bones.I'll probably update this review further since there are many things to say but for now please listen to other low rated reviews and do not insult your intelligence.
