Review title: I wasted two hours of my life.
Review_body: This movie was a shear disappointment to me. I absolutely loved the series to no end, and the first movie was mildly enjoyable but not as good as the series. This movie was overkill, a series and one movie was entirely enough. The jokes were not even mildly funny in any way. The problems these women face in this movie don't even entail sex, nor is the setting in the usual New York City. The actions of Samantha, though true to her nature are still disrespectful to the culture of the nation the girls visit. Charlotte is jobless, has a nanny (and probably a housekeeper) to take care of everything, and still is stressed about not having any time of her own. Miranda, doesn't hardly act like her normal character in the show. Carrie is essentially complaining about having what she strives so hard to get in the series, love and marriage with Mr. Big. The issues the girls are having are not even worthy of being called real issues, there is not any true sex or the city. All it really is, is lets bitch and complain while we go to Arabia! Suggest new title should be "Sexless and Cityless".

Review title: Michael Patrick King what have you done?
Review_body: I have loved Sex in the City since the show first came out. It was ground breaking and trend setting. Although the characters at time made you want to shake them and scream "Grow up" in the end they all had redeemable qualities. While the first movie failed to fully capture the magic of the show it was still enjoyable. Not so with the sequel. It starts off with the marriage of Stanford and Anthony. The wedding really serves no purpose but introduce an extremely nosy couple who make Carrie who was happy before start to question her marriage to Big. The question she has isn't, are we truly happy, or did I marry the right guy. Her question is does the fact that she and Big are not going out every night mean they're are a boring old couple with no social life? So instead of sitting down and talking with her husband like a grown up she runs off to her old apartment to hide for a few days. Miranda mean time is having issues with her boss she quits her job, and thats pretty much Miranda's whole storyline for the rest of the movie, done in the first 20 min. Charlotte finds motherhood to stressful and demanding on her despite the fact that she is a stay at home mom with a live in nanny. When Samantha makes a comment about the always bra less nanny Charlotte starts to worry that her wonderful devoted husband will have an affair. Samantha spends the entire movie trying to keep her sex drive up during menopause. When Samantha is invited by a rich sheik to visit his property in Abu Dabi and possibly do PR for him, something which any smart business woman would have seen as the opportunity of a lifetime, the girls decide to run away from their problems and go with her. Once they are in Abu Dabi the film gets even worse. The sheik is wonderfully generous flying them in first class, giving them the best suite in the hotel, each their own private butler, and every other comfort they could want. Samantha, who is supposed to be a successful business woman, should be treating this trip as a business trip but instead can only think of sex, and thumbing her nose at middle eastern culture. Charlotte is a bumbling idiot the entire trip. Miranda spends the trip trying to keep Samantha from getting thrown in jail for lewd behavior and trying to get the others to have some fun. Carrie mean while is still pondering her marriage. As she was leaving for the trip Big admitted to her he kind of liked the two days off when she left before and thinks they should do that every week. Carrie who started the whole thing by running off in the first place, worries about what this means for their marriage. While in Abu Dabi Carrie runs into Aiden her ex-fiancé, who she broke up with because he liked to stay in, eat KFC and watch baseball, and Carrie decides he might be the perfect replacement for Big who she's mad at because he likes to stay in, eat Japanese take out, and watch old movies and Deadliest Catch. Their time in Abu Dabi ends with them being asked to leave the hotel because Samantha can not control behavior. While leaving Carrie realizes that she left her passport back in the market place so all four go back for it. Charlotte in the mean time is acting like an idiot again and while being run out of town can only think of getting souvenirs for Harry and the girls. This leads to a scene with Samantha being accused of stealing a purse while her year supply of condoms comes spilling out for all to see. What does Samantha do? Does she do the classy thing and scoop her possession quietly. No she makes a scene and enrages a crowd of angry men. By this time in the movie I was routing for the mob of angry men to kick all but Miranda's ass. The movie then wraps up quickly and neatly with a bunch of voice overs, a quick crappy end to a crappy movie. I once loved Sex in the City. It used to have the best one liners ("oh my God she's fashion roadkill" and "I've been shoe shamed" were two of my favs) However in this movie we were treated to lame one liners like "Abu Dabi do" and "he's Lawrence of my labia". I actually cringed in embarrassment when I heard those lines. We also got the totally classy scenes of Samantha in her office with her panties around her ankles rubbing hormone cream on her female parts and later deep throating a pipe in a bar. And don't even get me started in the fashion. This show used to be trend setting with that, but every time Carrie and Samantha came out in a new outfit I heard other women the theater mumble how ugly it was. The writers, producers, and stars of this movie need to stop milking this franchise and let us remember these ladies fondly not as the shrews they've turned them into. If I could rate this lower then a 1 I would. I think Michael Patrick King and Sarah Jessica Parker should have to give everyone who wasted their movie on the movie a refund and an apology.

As a big fan of the show, I was really disappointed with the first movie. So why did I see the second one? Because I loved the series, and I realized just how much I miss it. I thought: Hey, at least I get to be in the company of Carrie, Samantha, Miranda and Charlotte, so wouldn't it be worth it? The answer is no. HELL no!!! Watching this movie is like seeing an old friend, who now is a pathetic shadow of what she used to be. The main "plot" is Carrie, who has to get used to the fact that marriage may not be, what she expected. When she finally realizes what we - the audience - have known all the time, you want to shake her and yell: "for God's sake woman! Get a grip!" The fact that they shamelessly use Aidan for 5 minutes in the progress is unforgivable.This time the girls go to Abu Dhabi instead of Mexico, and what a horrific trip this is! Except for some shopping and sightseeing, nothing really happens. Charlotte misses Harry and is afraid that he might have an affair with the nanny, Miranda, who has read all the travel books, gives us facts about the country, while Samantha... Oh Samantha... I sat in horror and watched her drop condoms all over a street, and afterward yelling F*CK YOU and giving the finger to the angry men, who surrounded her. I really disliked the way that they traveled to this foreign country, and seemed to have no respect for it's guidelines - except for Miranda.When the movie was over I was mad. What happened the humor? What happened with the witty, funny, lovely ladies we knew? But most important of all: If you make a movie with a duration of 2½ hours, you could at least throw in a plot.My friend liked it a little bit, but as she said: "It was only because I expected less than nothing".
Really, is Not!! Is just a random movie of 4 girls In New York (not the chitaury battle New York) just New York.

Review title: Worst movie for so many reasons but...
Review_body:
What can i say that hasn't already been said about the plot, the writing, the cultural insensitivity and stereotypes?
If you could get beyond all that, you might think, "Oh i can just watch it for the costume changes and to see the girls for nostalgia's sake." If you do, be warned: the lighting is AWFUL and makes the girls look like old hags in most scenes. It's really painful. The person in charge of lighting should be FIRED.

Review title: Sex and the Biddy in Another City
Review_body: If you're a huge fan of the TV series, like me, and fairly fond of the first film, like me, I strongly advise you not to watch this film. It makes a mockery of the characters and everything this franchise once stood for. When the TV series kicked off we had these four independent smart sexy women living in New York City facing the same challenges all women face - romantically, sexually and professionally. The end of the series gave each of the ladies a satisfying happy ending, where each embarks on a different chapter in her life. The first film brought them back, three years later, and we got to see them in a new light - dealing with finally settling down into the lives they'd always wished for that didn't quite turn out as planned. The second film brings them back, 2 happy endings and 2 years later, and it tries to be different from the first film. Perhaps trying to improve upon the slightly depressing tone of the first film, Sex and the City 2 tries to be more funny, more flashy and more colorful. It holds on for dear life to this notion that these women's happy endings must not be disturbed. Their relationships, their success and their life stories seem to be etched in stone now, making any attempt to create some sort of conflict in the actual plot of the film seem contrived, unnecessary and mostly foolish. The characters are reduced to self-indulgent, materialistic bitches that fail to be satisfied by absolutely everything - since they have it all: the money, the clothes, the husbands. At some point in the film you go from loving these characters to just hating their rich behinds. I presume the makers of this farcical sequel thought they'd try to take our minds off from our sad little recession-hit lives by taking us on an all expenses paid trip with the girls to Abu Dhabi. What they seem to have completely lost is their storytelling ability and a way to reach out to the audience. (not to mention that the title of the series is Sex and the City, the city being New York City, but what can we do - it's an all expenses paid trip after all) While the makers of the film focus on delivering ridiculous puns and changing the ladies' outfits in every consecutive scene, no one seems to have been the slightest bit concerned that not only has the film lost the plot, it's lost touch with reality. Carrie, Samantha, Miranda and Charlotte are no longer every woman. They are Carrie, Samantha, Miranda and Charlotte, the rich bigoted American feminists who have it all. They have become...celebrities. Are we supposed to be happy for them? For the sake of the show, yes. But do you really want to watch them rub it in your face along with awful puns and Liza Minnelli singing "Single Ladies" by Beyonce? No. I wish I hadn't.

I'd heard this film was terrible but I wasn't prepared for how obscenely awful it really is. The most toxic and cynical piece of rubbish I've ever had the mis-fortune of seeing. This is not cinema, this is one long, excruciating nightmare and should not be viewed by anyone. If there was an option to banish slime like this forever I would do it.

Review title: Why oh why did i go to see this 2!
Review_body: To say this film is awful is being understated about it. The film had no discernible plot. Carrie did my head in moaning and being selfish and the other women had little to do other then be clothes horses. And I'm sorry, but the fashion sadly missed the mark on most occasions.The men were underused AGAIN! I don't know why I thought it would be different in this film. The cameos were pointless. The first 'surpirse' was not at all surprising, you could see what was going to happen the minute the first scene had started.A lot of the good bits were in the ads and lost the punch for the film which was sadly missing any interesting things at all. Samantha was the same as she always is, Miranda didn't really do anything, Charlotte didn't really progress or change or grow and Carrie moaned so all in all nothing much different there then!I wanted and wished that this film would be so much more but I was sorely disappointed and won't be watching this again voluntarily.
Not the best way to promote Abu Dhabi and a total disrespect to the culture

Well as many other fans of the show I thought I could ignore the poor reviews and go and give this film a chance. Should have listened to the critics! Where to start, the gay wedding, Carries crown, and Liza made me cringe in my seat- it was OTT even for this show.The problems with Big and Carrie were hyped and then ignored, seriously why have Aiden in it at all?! The girls in the middle east were disrespectful to an entire culture- I thought for a minute they were trying to highlight the issue of women in some of these cultures, alas they merely mocked and ridiculed them, (Miranda had shown hope but in the end was as bad as the other three).I did laugh at some parts, however most of it was aimed at the actors for allowing this film to go ahead after fighting so hard to have a worthy first film as they didn't want to disappoint the fans. The producers, director and writers should be ashamed that this was pushed just to make more money rather than give a plot, and something for the fans to love.Overall it was too long, too full of celebrities just trying to show they were cool by making a cameo, strange clothing choices even for Carrie,and no point in my mind whatsoever.Lets just pretend this film wasn't made and that our journey with the girls ended with Carrie and Big getting married at the end of the first film, that is what I'm going to do anyway.

Stick to the first movie and the stick with the SATC Shows.Its boring, has no meaning.. Your better off waiting for it to come out on DVD People that like it are the people who have hopped on the Bandwagon and all of a sudden love this show or should i say Movie half the people who watch the new movie have no clue who half the characters are.I think the Producers knew the movie wasn't up to stranded as the first one but knew people will come out and watch it. an he was right, Cinemas everywhere where booked and you couldn't find a seat. They made a lot of money from this movie so if maybe a refund wouldn't hurt
As in the first film, there are also extremely empty scenes in this film. They took a half-hour movie closer to two and a half hours with empty scenes.

Review title: Bandwagon haters can't, or at least shouldn't stop the fun
Review_body: OK - so Sex and the City 2 isn't rocket science, is this something we are just figuring out? I am only compelled to review this movie because I noticed that most of the negative reviews center around the same fundamental principles and they are: a) The movie does not take place in NYC from start to finish (boo hoo). b) The movie is not PC when it comes to women's stereotypes and the sexually-repressed Middle East (boo hoo). c) and the movie was too "over-the-top" with regards to fashion and people's living of their lives (again, boo-freaking-hoo).What has made the Sex and the City franchise so good in the past and what drives millions to watch it is essentially three major principles - friendship, sex-love-romance, and fun, and SATC2 mixes all three together again in a package that is as bizarre, over-the-top (did you SEE the gay wedding??), and tongue-and-cheek as it is funny, and it IS funny. As promised, the producers of "2" let the story follow a romp of comedy, and while some of it is so high-brow it may annoy us typical "9 to 5'ers" who scrape from paycheck to paycheck to make ends meet, most is sophomoric and flat-out blatant, especially the thousand or so gay jokes that kick-off the movie and really, never truly stop.The movie is unrealistic, shouldn't be taken seriously, is not going to uncover layers of character fortitude, and will make absolutely no push or argument for an Oscar. It's a stab at comedy through the SATC program that has relied so heavily on sex to sell, and the same holds true for the film. I do not own SATC DVD's, I've seen the show only in passing on HBO and I only watched SATC1 about a year ago on cable.In a day when romantic comedies and chick flicks fall flat on their faces and offer almost nothing of meritous value, both in production and in finished product, SATC2 takes you on a comedic journey and does it lavishly, wasting next to nothing. You'll feel as if the film dumped just as much money on production as it makes you believe it's four principals do as they cavort around their day-to-day lives. Along the way, you get just enough on each character to set you up for what has happened up until now, and where the story will go when it wraps.Again - Gone With the Wind it is not. take it for what it is, let your guard down, and enjoy the movie!

I am a HUGE fan of the series and the first movie. Thanks to all of the "fans" horrible reviews I was scared to go see the sequel...I went to see it tonight and I Abso-f***ing-lutely LOVED it!!!The movie was funny. It isn't meant to be taken super seriously and neither was the series. It is light and fun. To everyone saying that the movie is about nothing...it is about friendship and where these four women are in their relationships. Keeping the spark in your relationship, taking care of children and balancing work and home life are REAL problems and concerns that all women deal with. Bottom line if you are a true fan of Sex and the City please don't let the bad reviews stop you from seeing the girls in this wonderful movie!

I have never been a fan of the show because I have too much testosterone, I guess. Sex And The City is played by women, for women. My wife has always been a fan of the series, so I do have seen quite some episodes. I do understand why women find it interesting: the glamorous clothes and shoes, the characters, the presence or absence of romance, etc.After seeing the first film (by my wife's initiative, of course) I still could understand if 'some' fans enjoyed it. For me it looked like an extra long episode of the show. Sex And The City 2 is something completely different to anything that relates to the previous film and the TV show... in a bad way. Even my wife could not ignore the annoyance of some scenes.An over the top wealthy, neurotic-racist, whining-like-little-children, over-aged-scary-looking and some way-too-skinny-women, horror show is what you will get in this sequel.The New York Magazine itself summed it up very good: "The most depressing thing about Sex and the City 2 is that it seems to justify every nasty thing said and written about the series and first feature film."Stop the self humiliation of something that once was adored by so many women...

Review title: It's hard to imagine how this movie could have been worse
Review_body: To quote Carrie, "oh how the mighty have fallen". This quote applies to the movie on so many levels. What was once an great show, with captivating story lines and decent acting, has turned into an over-the-top, pun-filled (seriously...inter-fun-tion??), 2+ hr display of this season's haute couture. Save your money & buy a Vogue.Also, on a side note, even if they are just making cameo appearances, how do actresses like Liza Minelli & Penelope Cruz go from starring in cinematic masterpieces to touching this garish Hollywood trash?The only reason this review gets 1 extra star is because the soundtrack & scenery was pretty good.

I see that two types of people went to see this movie. Long time fans who, in spite of everything, care about these characters and want to see what's new with their lives.. and people who heard of the series, don't follow it as well, and saw the movie with friends. I am seeing that the later of this group are the ones who see nothing wrong with the movie. I feel that real loyal fans can see all the problems this movie has. While on it's own, I can see how it might be entertaining to watch with it's silly jokes, and almost child like antics. However, add this to a 10+ year story line of 4 woman maturing into middle-aged adults, and fans are left scratching our heads asking what we just saw.The series was a mix of serious issues mixed in with comedy and let's face it, some silliness. The first movie dealt more with serious. This one clearly is way more about the silliness. However After so many years, and clearly after watching the woman mature as they did in the last movie, this one felt so completely out of place and out of touch. It's hard to believe that the character I liked most was Big! (Chris Noth). Though I understand Carrie's worry about not wanting to lose her husband to the TV, the way they tried to get this problem across failed completely. Not only that, I thought him wanting to share that moment together of laying in bed and watching old movies like that, was way more personal and touching then some $20,000 necklace. The fact that Carrie still refuses to grow up about some issues is beyond annoying. They already touched on the "my love interest is an introvert and wants to stay home" plot with her already. With Aidan. And she learned her lesson then! Miranda and Charlotte were the only two who I felt, saved the movie. They did rush the plot of Miranda hating her boss, but I think it showed how much she matured as woman in a family and picked them over the job and dealing with someone who didn't respect her. At times she came across as very silly, but after leaving a job that you took so seriously for 20 years, It's understandable that she let go the way she did. Not freaking out about having the internet every two seconds. Char, well.. I understand having a 2 year old who wont stop crying and there is nothing you can do to help. Plus trying to take care of a 5 year old who acts out cause she is clearly being ignored, would cause any mother to break down. Since at that time, she was home alone without her help. (I've done that. It's hard) However, her whole issue with the bra-less nanny, was beyond ridiculous. No mother and wife would allow their nanny to dress like that around their family. All you have to do is pull them aside and tell them "You can see your boobs through your clothes. Can you please cover yourself up more while around my family" That's how an adult handles that situation. Samantha acted like a complete child.Lastly, as an American, I am completely offended by the direction and underlining insult that movie directed towards an Arab Country. After Sept 11th? Taking 4 New York woman into an Arab nation and have them be insulting and not understanding at all towards their customs (except Miranda), is just so beyond.. I don't even have words. It was beyond insulting and totally insensitive. I can't believe that point of view was allowed to even be addressed. I get that it's just a movie, and we do to watch them to get away from the real world. But that doesn't give any movie the excuse to insult another culture. I can understand that how woman are treated in Arab countries can be a real shock to this 4 very empowered woman.. but they are from New York. There is no excuse for their lack of respect and understanding. New York City is more open to people of MANY cultures more then any other city in this country. I'm half their age and I understand it. I might not respect it myself, but I would never go over there and give them the finger and shove condoms in their faces. I hate the impression this movie gave about American's. I'm honestly surprised any of the actors agreed to do this movie.

Review title: A Garbage, Extremely Cringey Movie That Ruins A Franchise.
Review_body: Wow. Just wow. What an awful movie. This movie made me hate every character and throw up in my mouth with every bit of lame, contrived dialogue and forced stupid scenarios. Please. Do not watch this. I wish someone would have warned me. AND NOW I CAN NEVER UNSEE IT.

1. Charlotte cant handle motherhood with maids, full time nanny and a millionaire husband 2. Carrie's selfish single lifestyle attitude towards her marriage to big 3. Samantha fu*ks anything has a pause 4. Marinade has pretty much no character in the plot ++ 5. there is no plot6. the fashion is good but do they really need Christina Dior to ride a camel and couture for UAE market? 7. thought they all millionaires (with all the clothes and shoes they are wearing ) cant afford 5500 each /night hotel or just move to a normal room for a night instead of catching a crappy taxi running out of the country? 8. what does the guy couple do once again? robbing banks? with a wedding like that they must be! ....... too many to conclude...too little time as i have already wasted 2.5 hrs of my life the most important one there is no fa*king 'city' ! why don't you just call the movie 'sex in middle east'? 'menopause'? ?how the mighty fall?

I was so excited to see this movie and I couldn't wait for it to come out! I was very disappointed when I read the reviews of the movie. I hesitated dragging my husband on our night out to see it, but we were in for a treat! Sex and the City 2 was made with a different outlook than the series and the first movie and that is why a lot of people didn't like it. It focuses on the married lives of 3 of the 4 friends and it has no longer that cool-single-new york city lifestyle happening, where we constantly watched Carrie dragging herself around the city looking for love and looking to be loved. The single crowd could no longer identify with the characters since they were all married and Samantha, who is the only one with the crazy fun single lifestyle has menopause and gets comments on being old for her fashion style. If I was single, after seeing this movie, I would have also hated it and found it repulsive to watch, since its focusing on married people and the ones who are not married or getting married are old and menopausal. Nevertheless, as for married people I find it a very good entertaining film, easy and fun to watch, with problems that married couples can related to. The middle-eastern experience was fun, since they have played too much the new york city lifestyle and it was very refreshing to have them in a different scenery, and it gave the movie a funny twist. I expected it to be a lot worse. Not bad for Carrie and her learning experience on love and marriage! If you like this kind of movies and shows, don't hesitate to watch it!!!

Review title: J'adore Le Sex and le City !
Review_body: "Sex and the City 2" was, to say this first of all, mostly not like I expected it to be when I was watching the Trailers etc. The Story might be not that great, but what "Big" Drama's do we want to see now after they said "I do" ? The Aidan thing was pretty clever, and actually I thought there didn't happen enough ! A kiss is just not enough ! The End of the movie fails a little bit, it's to fast and it comes without a warning. It's like: So that's the story, thanks for watching and BOOM Credits roll in ... I wasn't anticipating that the story would be the important thing in this movie, it's about the Girls, it always was this way and I hope will stay this way for a third Part. The actors are as great as always ... sure they got old, but they still kick ass. I love the Soundtrack, the clothes, the fun, the friendship, the guys and of course the gals. And at least the story was still so much more fun than the first one ! All that Drama is gone and now Carrie and Mr. Big are just a married couple, but nothing about Big cheating on Carrie is true ! Don't know if that was a PR Gag or something ... but at least it isn't that way around in the movie. And be sure that Samantha with a menopause, however will still be Samantha and there are some freakin' hot guys in Abu-Dhabi. Miley Cyrus is also pretty sweet in her 50 Seconds on Screen. The best Thing in the whole movie are the set's ! The Hotel and everything they experience in Abu-Dhabi is so beautiful. It's exactly as good as the first movie was.If you loved the first one ... you'll die for this !

I watched this movie as wife really wanted to see it. Let's put it this way - even if you get a free pirated version of the movie - still do not waste your time on this crap! I do not understand how did this movie made over 286 million. This is nothing but a story about 4 mid-aged women trying and acting like teens and it was PURE torture.This movie was disrespectful portrayal of North American women and an insult to foreign cultures.Do yourself a favour - if you happen to be in a situation where you cannot avoid watching this movie - take a few sleeping pills beforehand! You will thank me later.

Simply there is nothing in the movie except of scenes with boobs and saying the F word from time ti time. No plot, no idea, boring for 99% of the time. I do wonder how it can have 4 on the scale... I guess the series lovers put high scores on it. If you want to know the biggest "idea" from the movie without watching it, there you go : "Do or do not people have to spend all the time together after marriage or can they meet other people and spend the time on their own?". The answers however You have to figure out for yourself, not going to happen simply while watching this movie. Please have a walk or so instead of an idea of borrowing and watching this piece of ....

Review title: What's all the hate for? I liked it!
Review_body: All in all I thought it was good! A bit insensitive and rude, that surely is true, but nonetheless deserves a decent review. Not as good as the first one and not a lot of emotional depth like the first one, but worth seeing and fun to watch. One thought that might have good for the film was going in depth with carrie and the others emotional turmoil. In addition, the meeting with Aidan should have been a little more drawn out, but I was glad she didn't sleep with him. I definitely liked how bug forgave her. You could tell there was a lot of love there, because he was so forgiving. In conclusion, there should be a third one made to end the series on a more emotional note. The 2nd one is good, but for the third one, some fluff (a lot I should say) should be taken out and replaced with more personal situations.

Review title: Please don't drag your Boyfriend to this .. we shouldn't suffer as well
Review_body: From never seen a single episode of Sex in the City, I was dragged to this on a Sunday afternoon by my fiancée'. What happened next was close to having my happy chap being slammed in between bricks for 2 hrs+.As far as I can tell these super rich women that have zero grasp of reality are in a group that spend their time shopping, slating their bf;s/husbands and generally doing sweet fa for loads of money.The general plot line , if there is such a thing seems to be Samantha (the slutty one)a publicist gets invited by a Arab hotel owner all expenses to review and help with the hotels image. She somehow drags along horse faced parker, the scary looking ginge and the dark haired dense one.What happens next is Red Rum Parker does a costume change every 5 mins, like wearing a ball gown in a boiling hot middle eastern market..? why??? The slutty one trying to simply get more rides than a Blackpool roller-coaster, The dense dark haired one dealing with her inner emotion of being a mother and the ginge's passion for knowledge and learning.( on a note how she managed to stay pasty white and not burn to a crisp throughout the film is beyond me)2 hrs of this crap... seriously!.. queue a sub plot of the old one being done for having sex on a beach ( wow didn't see that coming )and the '3:15 from Donnington' Parker kissing some random man,even some slow-mo scene involving the Austrialian rugby team!? Every actress seems to milks every screen minute to show how pretty and flowing they can make any dress look. It's beyond me how scenes like the condom market scene or the frankly insulting beyond belief Gucci under burkhas scene was kept in. Did the writers seriously expect us believe that such a character (Samantha) would have no respect for another countries traditions or rules?? I'm not a woman so I cant understand the appeal this series gets.Horse face Parker should be given some sort of uber award for managing to milk 2 films and multiple series out of this crap. On a finishing note- It was way too long, had little or no plot, wooden acting and borderline racist ideas for plot fillers, If your a woman and you loved the series - fine go watch it, my fiancée thinks its personally better than the first so if your a uber fan you'll prob love it.

Like many other reviewers, I was a BIG fan of the series, and although the first movie wasn't great, and despite the mediocre (being nice) initial reviews, I decided to give this a go. So I settled in with two girlfriends, and all it took was the first setting of Stanford and Anthony's wedding to know this wasn't going to be anything like the series and I'm amazed this was actually by the same people. As Carrie said later in the movie "I don't think we're in Kansas anymore". My friends and I watch disbelieving as Liza Minelli "performed" Beyonce, and a couple of strangers told Carrie and Big they were basically doomed to be lonely or bad people just for not wanting children. We were shocked, and I have to say, embarrassed. The high point was the re-emergence of Smith. A high point which lasted all of 4, 5 minutes?! Then pretty inexplicably we're off to UAE, and Miranda was treating us to Abu Dhabi for Dummies for most of the remainder of the film. Aidan's re-appearance felt completely contrived, against character and un-needed, and he disappeared again just as non-sensically. Samantha managed to insult an entire culture, and apparently get away with it - and I'm sorry, the character was never stupid, nor that dismissive of culture and beliefs. It felt completely pointless and against all previous laws of SATC. The best part, and I did genuinely laugh, was Charlotte being drunk. And if that's the best part, then we're in trouble. So Carrie loses her passport, and miraculously it's still in the market, so endeth another 2 minute plot. And the girls escape an angry mob by yet again insulting the culture before the end of the movie which again seemed to come from nowhere and dis-count the previous 2 hours... All in all, a very big disappointment, against the series and characters, non-sensical and pointless plots, embarrassing and uncomfortable at times. At its height SATC was never about full on comedy, it was real life drama that we could relate to. My friend turned to me at the end and said "I didn't know we were watching a Carry On film", and I couldn't have put it better myself.

I followed the TV series. I saw the first movie. I'm not a fanatic fan, but a fan nonetheless. I thought the series was good, some years better than others, but overall funny, smart and what made it good was TIGHT writing. A lot was delivered in span of that TV show. Not as much was delivered in the first movie, but still enough to keep you hooked. But this one? OMG! It was the WORST movie I have ever seen. Literally. I kept thinking didn't anyone EDIT this script? I almost walked out before it ended, but didn't because I knew Mr. Big would reappear and he's worth just looking at on a big screen. But please...the plot was ludicrious and took us out of 'The City' which IS one of the characters. The acting and character development was so lame, and empty it was like they were all cardboard cutouts of themselves. It lacked '2 year follow-up' and development of the group. They were just 'plopped' down and twirled around until another costume change. If you're going to have a sequel give us something, not just costume changes. Give us the depth the show had. There was SO much that could have been done between the last movie and this. It was about as boring as watching Carrie and Big sit on the couch and watch black and white old movies. No, it was worse than that. It was like watching the make-up dry on Liza Minelli's face.Awful. Stay away from this movie. It's not even worth renting. Skip it. You'll be upset with King for writing this piece of garbage and mad at the actors for selling out and acting (if you can call it that) in it.I had read other reviews on this site and thought, oh, it can't be THAT bad. The last movie got panned, and it was still a fun little romp. And it was. People laughed, cheered, and clapped in that movie. This one, NO ONE in the audience laughed except once. I think they were all in shock like I was wondering what happened to the writing and acting that we were so used to enjoying.

Review title: Great movie, and no matter what other people say!
Review_body: Loved it. People keep complaining that it wasn't at all like the series and so what? Who said that movie should be exactly like series? It has a charm on it's own. Others say that problems that were portrayed in the film were just to simple. Well, hello? Maybe just those who said it are just to shallow. It is not easy to bring up kids even with a nanny, it is complicated if you meet an old flame, because even when we part with someone we loved, still there's something left deep in our heart that can easily come to the surface when we meet them. And if a woman goes into menopause it is also very difficult to come to terms with it, as for a woman it means that basically her youth and beauty faded away, and does any woman wants to realize that??? And also, what exactly did you expect from that genre??? Aids, cancer, teenage pregnancy and homicide??? Other people comment that Carrie looks 10 years older. If you'd know the dates from first-last series, you'd realize that it's been 12 years from the first episode and 8 years from the last one. There are moments that probably shouldn't be there but generally I can not say that it is a bad movie and yes, I will watch it again. There is a huge problem at present day and it's not with movies but with people who watch them. Every time they watch a movie they want something new, something more and more exciting, something that they haven't seen yet. Well, we live in the 21 century, and I'm pretty sure that if we haven't seen it all yet, then definitely most of it.People set to high expectations for films, they expect not to be entertained but simply to see miracles. And when that doesn't happen they get disappointed and leave bad reviews. How "great" is that!So you can complain all you want, analyze what they are wearing, what they were saying, how they were acting etc and be disappointed at the end or you can just lay back, relax, watch it and enjoy it as it is and be in a great mood. The choice is yours.

I loved SATC2! This is a movie for women to escape reality for a bit. When your little you dream about living in castles, wearing beautiful clothes and having a handsome prince come and sweep you away! As you grow up you come to realise this never happens and reality is nothing like the stories we are told when we are little. Now i'm in my late 20's for me Sex and the City is a return to fantasy but as a grown up. I loved that I got to escape reality for two and a bit hours. The shoes, clothes, wonderful group of friends, exotic setting and handsome men.....What more could a girl dream of?Come on people Sex and the City is to women, what James Bond is to men!!

They get what they want only to be insecure......and their spoiled...only Miranda is real, Samantha is disgusting Charlotte and Mr Big should know better..Carrie is sad and selfish.I wish they had better writers.. And watching TV is not the end of world.

Review title: Sad to say, but I was very disappointed.
Review_body: I started watching the show on demand with my sister shortly before the first movie came out. I absolutely fell in love with the show and ended up buying the entire series on DVD. I also enjoyed the first movie - it kept the tone of the show and the characters maintained their personalities, etc.I was so disappointed by the 2nd movie. -There was barely a plot. After two hours in the theater, I only remember one significant thing happening. -The characters were not themselves. Carrie made one pun that I can remember, Charlotte was so weak and unhappy through the whole thing, and Miranda was way too excited and happy about everything (I missed the realist/cynic). Samantha was the only one who got to maintain part of her personality, and even that was weaker than on the show. -Too many celebrity cameos that didn't really contribute to the story -Too much pandering to the audience. It was all about saying things that would make women cheer in the theater. It's hard to raise a child *cheers* Men don't like women to speak because they are afraid of strong women *cheers* let's all sing "I am woman" *cheers* -Too many things happened that had no explanation and weren't built upon. (EX: When did Stanford and Anthony start dating?) -Where was everyone else? I think Miranda and Charlotte's husbands each had one line. Magda made a few faces. They focused completely on the 4 ladies and Big, but there still wasn't really a story.Overall, it just made me sad to see how much potential the movie had (why didn't they show more of the 80s? etc.). It just wasn't the Sex and the City that I came to love! I don't think I will even buy it when it comes out on DVD.

Review title: No Sex... made in Middle East!!!!
Review_body: Two days ago I got my best friend and went to see Sex and the City. And us, as so many others before us were not impressed. When I got out of the theater my notion was that the production team had no script what-so-ever in mind, and they just scribbled down 4 little plots that could (and were resolved)in a five minute radius. The rest of the film is summed up to easy jokes and lavish (but not so fine) fashion. That was not a film, it was project runway with continuity issues. Don't get me wrong,it was fine for an all-girls night out but it was not the Sex and the City that we all know and love (I still watch the series in re-runs). 1st issue: Where is the City? I mean 80% of the movie is set in the Middle-East (and filmed in Marocco actually). It should be called Sex and the City on vacation. For me it should have been half the movie in NYC and the other half in M.E. 2nd issue: It was too long. For a film that was so sloppy written and had little to no plot, it should have ended sooner. 3rd issue: Camera angles people, editing room, filters. The ladies are growing and some shots were really unflattering especially for Carrie and Sharlotte (oh God the close-up when SJP puts the eyeliner! If I was SJP I would cut that scene).Samantha was OK and Miranda for me was gorgeous.(her style has really evolved from the series). 4th issue: What happened to the characters? We're used to Carrie being whiny, selfish and messing it up but she sure did a number this time. For a girl who spend 6 years chasing Mr. Big (Chris Noth was great by the way) she surely messed it up with the guy she "allegedly" loves. I liked Sharlotte's storyline (though she went a bit overboard)and I liked Miranda's too. Actually I liked Miranda more than the other three. And Samantha, oh God Samantha. We know she's over the top, but man that was too much. Aside the sex-drive, Sam Jones is also a PR Pro. Let me tell you something; she didn't act like one, not in the very least. Also it was no wonder the Emirates didn't allow them to shoot the movie there. Some part were really disrespectful to the culture there. I'm not a fan of romantic comedies. I always prefer a good shoot-out that a tear fest. But Sex and the City is my guilty pleasure because is more comedy with a spice of Love. I couldn't find that spice, not in this movie. If they are to make a third, they should pay very close attention to the script. Otherwise leave a fine franchise at rest. Peace.

And it did have some plot.This one though, is so bad, it left me cringing throughout the movie. No plot. And oh my god, enough about the HORMONES!!!! Review title: Don't hate if it's not your genre!!!!!
Review_body: A lot of bad reviewers are just haters, SAVE VOTING FOR PEOPLE WHO ENJOY THE GENRE!! I don't get why people have to hate on movies if they don't like the genre, just don't watch it in the first place because then you're biased. This movie is enjoyable and funny!!!!!!! You just have to watch it with friends and you'll have stuff to talk about and things to recognize within your own relationships/life. It takes you out of this world into a glamorous/rich world for a while which is nice. I found some of the outfits really over the top, who would wear some of those in real life? But that's why it is a movie, to entertain and take us to another place. Don't think about it too much, just enjoy!!

I really don't understand people, especially fans which didn't enjoy it! I am not a "fan", I just love the series, have enjoyed the 1st movie and went to this one just to have a good time and see the girls again, like old friends. I have read many bad reviews just before seeing the movie so I was prepared to see nothing special, just fashion, no story line etc...But yesterday... what a surprise I had! I was in the screen during all the movie. I forgot everything: my life, my problems, me...I was with them, completely! And at the end I thought to myself that people didn't understand actually that movie. For example : the gay wedding is too much. OK, but...THEY KNOW IT; they are aware and they're joking about that, about themselves, about everything. The movie is funny, funny, funny, they are not serious. At the same time the movie is not superficial. It's not ABOUT fashion, ABOUT, shoes (not enough shoes by the way ;-) ) It's also about life, friendship, love, passion, etc etc etc...and we have a GREAT TIME!!! It's just a question of understanding! Don't take it too seriously!

I loved the series, absolutely adore it. I loved the first movie, I thought it was fantastic and it really felt like closure for me. This movie was terrible, undeniably offensive, and advanced nothing in the story line at all! Honestly, how did anyone enjoy it all? I was cringing most of the time, as soon as they started poking fun at the burkhas I knew it was going down hill. The entire undertone was "fuck this backwards country!" although by the end, Samantha certainly wasn't hinting it subtly. Apart from the entire cringe that was these girls in the Middle East, what story line was there?! Honestly, what was there? Oh Charlotte is stressed out. Okay? Carrie got a bad book review. Okay? This movie couldn't have more honestly been a desperate grab for cash, because nothing else like a real plot seemed to be even been considered. I'd even be willing to overlook the absurdity of Carrie meeting Aiden in the market, if the rest of the movie just wasn't so terrible. The only part I really enjoyed was a two second clip of the 'gay' servant holding the bags and twinkling his eyes. I will never watch this movie again, pretend it doesn't exist, and go back to having the first movie (which I watched three times over 2 days) by my closure for the series. What a way to taint something I love so much.

Review title: Light, easy, clear...what else do you need?
Review_body: After reading all these negative reviews about the movie I was pretty pessimistic, but hello, it wasn't bad at all...Just like the series,the movie is very kind, very encouraging and even relaxing. You see the same smiles of the women who were actually never supposed to be awkwardly beautiful and are just getting naturally older. They have always played the roles of just normal, ordinary women. And they do it nicely. Well, I agree that in comparison to the series the movie was a little shallow at some moments, but again what is so bad about it? You get something different, kind of a new approach to the life of the same people. But the language remained the same, and that is absolutely one of the greatest thing about the whole project.All in all, I was feeling relaxed and not bored during the movie and after it.

Review title: It's a film called Sex and the City NOT War and Peace
Review_body: This is the first time I have written a review and what better a start than after all the scathing reviews (the one's I have read have been mainly by Men by the way). My favourite Carrie outfit was the one she wore when she dined with Aiden. This is a movie NOT real life, so many haters on here, I beg the question, why did you go to see it if you didn't like the series/first film etc!!I do hope they make no 3, I will be a fan for life and it is only a fairytale when its on screen so people don't take it too seriously, lifes too short.

--Warning contains spoilers— "Sex and the city 2!" These were the words uttered out of my girlfriend's mouth during our debate on which film to watch at our local cinema on the cheap Wednesday. Unfortunately for me my flawed and fractured argument on why she should endure (the appealing) Prince of Persia didn't hold up, and we finally compromised on the Chick Flick.Upon entering and realising I was one of nine guys in a packed cinema, (three of which were old, sitting in corners rubbing their legs,) I decided to cling to my only shred of self dignity which is that I'm a film student and therefore could hopefully pass off this visit as an educational excursion.Now as a guy, I'm a complete novice to the Sex in the City series or the previous film, and therefore will be presenting my review based on an autonomous viewing.First of all, it was nice to see a film where the female characters interacted with one another in a pleasant, likable fashion without any odious or indeed jocular bitches. (The former relates to Mean Girls and the latter predominantly to Jessica in Sorority Row.) The film was witty, interesting to a point and exuded lofty aspirations as it tried to compact the lives of all four characters within the film utilising omniscient narration, along with a voice over from Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker.) Unfortunately this is pretty much all I have to say about the film which is positive. The main marital scene used to introduce all the characters involved was completely pointless. The "brooms" featured again once in the whole movie; so what was the point in introducing them in the first place? There were numerous possibilities for setting all the characters in the same place: Anniversaries, tragic accidents, even traditions which could've initiated the film on a more enhanced level.My next problem was with the voice over. I found it erratic, incoherent and inconsistent. An example of a great voice over would be in 'Breakfast Club' (1985), where it's present at the beginning and resolution of the film, conveying the subtle character development. Here it flashed up seemingly at random to foist information on the audience, half of which at least could be derived from simply watching the thing.Thirdly, the plot entailed multiple problems. We seemed to spend a great deal of time investigating two of the four women's lives. Miranda's (Cynthia Nixon) family received a miniscule amount of screen time; and we weren't even shown Samantha's (Kim Cattrall) home life.Finally, for this review, the film was far too long and dragged.So why did I give it five stars? Well it made me laugh several times so it succeeded in part as a comedy. Despite the copious problems with the film I enjoyed it and only wish it had been reduced in size; and contained a consistent and coherent plot.Once the opening credits flashed up on the screen, I proceeded to hastily drag my numb bum off the seat and vacate the cinema before anyone recognised me.

Review title: We're off to see the cheik the wonder cheik of Abu Dhabi
Review_body: As a Middle Easterner who left the highly conservative country of Saudi Arabia seeking freedom, I really hoped that this film would tastefully draw attention on some important issues like human law violations when it comes to freedom of speech not freedom to F**K. I thought maybe Carrie will get in some trouble for writing a piece on some of the outdated traditions of the Arabian Gulf. King, however preferred to give the platform to Samantha to do all of the 'oh no they didn't' for them.I love the series and I liked the first film because we needed real closure. However, they seem to have ran out of idea's and decided to turn to fiction rather than what the show has always been about which was reality and human relations. This film lacks a lot of research when it comes to UAE and the Arabian Gulf. Facts are misrepresented and although they did reveal some realities, the film reminded me of Aladdin the animated film where they embark on their riffraff journey. Forced adventure and negligence to find the line between provocative and distasteful. **SPOILER**One thing that really disturbed me was the scene where Charlotte tells Carrie that she's using her Christian name York as opposed to her Jewish name Goldenblatt. Carrie asks her why and she quickly replies repetitively "we're in the Middle East" but then Carrie reaffirms that UAE is the "New Middle East".Now this would've been a wonderful message to send out if it wasn't for the ignorance of the writers. The UAE and most gulf countries do not object to the entry of Jews in their countries but they do object to the entry of Israelis due the political problems between Israel and most Arab countries. Carrie's response to Charlotte would've been an ever greater one if Samantha did not end the trip by saying "new Middle East my a$$" . I ponder as to what was the intention of the whole new ME thing to begin with? If the four sexy new yorkers are there to break stereotypes or reinforce them ?This film lacked a sense of reality and lacked a lot of research.I give it a 4/10. I loved seeing my girls again but I'm afraid my girls have gone too fictional for my taste.

I really did like it. I am a long time watcher of the shows and absolutely loved the first movie. This movie wasn't as good as the first but it's a sequel so you can't really expect it to be. I think any mother who's gone through some of the struggles that Miranda and Charlotte face, and any woman who's married that's experienced disappointed expectations for what marriage would be like, like Carrie did, will like the fact that this movie touches on these issues but also does it within a ridiculous fantasy world so it doesn't get too serious to be depressing. It was absolutely fun and fabulous and is exactly who and where you'd expect these characters to really be two years later. It's really enjoyable once you stop trying to notice all the outlandish stuff. I've read the reviews by critics that criticized the fact that this movie lacked the heartfelt friendship content that the first had, but it absolutely had that- it was just another side of their friendship. I recommend it wholeheartedly to the SATC followers but I can see how silly it might be to people who don't know these characters.

This is a feel good movie that was good from beginning to end.. its worth seeing!! I loved it and can not wait to see over and over again. Not sure why this review is requiring to write 10 full lines..I think this is the reason why there are not more positive review..so for that I feel bad for the previous reviews .

Review title: Not as good as the 1st movie but still alright
Review_body: Summary: Good not great. If you miss the ladies, you'll want to see it regardless.The 1st sex and the city movie was a gem to me. I loved it, I thought it was bright and all us SATC fans were dying to catch up with the characters and where they'd been since the series. There were also surprises in it Steve cheating!, the way Carrie gets left at the alter, Charlotte pregnant.SATC2 had none of that in my opinion.NO SURPRISES: I really wasn't surprised about anything. Aidan is back (OK we all knew that), Charlotte gets a nanny, Miranda quits her job, nothing really earth shattering here.WHY: I had heard about Penelope Cruz being in this movie for a while now and that she would be a potential other love interest for BIG. While I don't care much for her I thought, hmm OK, interesting twist, I can see a good complication there for Carrie. Nope. She was there for 1 scene -maybe 5 mins and poof no more Penelope. I ask myself, really? Why was she even in the movie? They could have hired any good looking woman with decent acting skills to play that role. I kept thinking she would pop up again later (possibly BIG cheating on Carrie with Penelope after hearing her Aidan news) but it never happened. Pointless.SMITH: Why tease the audience with Smith reconnecting with Samantha if he wasn't going to even be a real part of this story? Other than him helping Sam connect with the guy wanting to build hotels he wasn't really in this movie. Again, huh? Pointless deux.A PLUS: SATC2 does have something going for it that the original did not. The characters were more themselves this time around--or rather more in line with the personalities seen on the series were. I always felt the 1st movie was great but the characters were a wee bit different, almost too evolved. I missed these girls more--they were funnier.The Clothes: I'm not sure why I've seen repeated reviews about the clothes sucking in this movie because I have to disagree. I thought they were great. Fashion is ever evolving and I happen to think Pat Fields did a great job keeping these girls looking great but all with their distinct personal style. Great to see Miranda not looking 100 percent perfect all the time and having some casual attire moments. She was way way too dressy in the 1st one (although stylishly so). And Carrie back to wearing see thru dresses with visible panties, tacky but that was the Carrie I remember, glad to see that part of her still exists!BIG and Carrie: Loved seeing them together more and their domestic issues. I think the best part of their scenes came when he picked her up at her old place. There was a collective awww in the crowd. Loved it. Though I think BIG forgave her too fast for the kiss, but whatever. And is it me or is Chris Noth looking 50 million times better than the 1st movie. He lost weight and is looking great!General Plot: A bit all over the place in my opinion. I think they were trying to do too much at once and I don't think it always worked. I also think that most of the fans, love the New York of SATC and would have preferred to spend most of the time there versus abu dhabi. I would have also loved to see Carrie writing more. Did we really see her writing much at all in this movie? Blink and you missed it.Lastly: Was anyone else wondering why those Liza Minelli scenes lasted so long? And was anyone else as disturbed as I was? No offense to the Liza fans but eh...I think we could have done without most of it. Just like the girls singing. It was cute, but did it need to go on so long?In Short: Don't get me wrong, I didn't hate the movie but I'm not sure it lived up to my expectation of what I had hoped it would be. The ladies themselves were in fine form though. Personally better than they were the 1st go round. They may want to take more time creating a better script (as with the 1st one) if they decide to do a SATC3.

I don't really have much to add as there are some really comprehensive and spot-on reviews already on here. All I can say is that I don't see the point of releasing such drivel. I'm embarrassed as a long-time fan to have looked so forward to this film, and instead I feel like I wasted that loyalty on a pretentious and contrived waste of my time. Its very unfortunate that the girls (or NOT) are going out this way. REWRITE PLEASE! In the rewrite, please remember the "and the city" part. What group of executives thought it would make a good film to have these women in the UAE? I've been there myself many times and even with that familiarity and ability to relate to the situation, found it an utterly pointless story line and nevermind a scenario to waste most of the film on. Just constant disappointment after the other. Very few highlights (thank goodness for Miranda!) and one semi-fun scene with her and Charlotte getting a bit boozy. Other than that nothing. One part I disagree with other reviewers - don't get DVD. Wait until you can see it free on your cable movie channels!

According to the IMDb reports, more than half (1000+)of the raters for this movie are MEN. Just saying.I've read a lot of bad comments from people who say they're fans of the show, but I can't for the love of me understand why they dislike the movie so horribly.To me as a woman, the entire series was a learning tool for sex and relationships, each episode a different topic from cheating, anal sex, homosexuality and even funky spunk - all in the WOMAN's perspective. Every issue known to single woman in the dating world was out in the open and uncensored. This movie was just a continuation of that learning experience brought into the married life. Charlotte coping with the hardships of motherhood, Miranda making choices between work and family, Carrie adjusting to the realities of married life without children, and a little insight on the gay marriage of Stanford and Anthony. Everyone had a problem that so many women can relate to. Each character gave us completely different perspectives of the issue that is marriage and commitment.The writers of the movie have done remarkably well keeping the characters consistent throughout the series and movies. The only difference you may notice is that there may be a little less spice and a little less sex. That is because the movie is the "winding down" of the series where all the women are finally married and settled (minus Samantha because that's her character) therefore, there won't be as much drama as the series. What did you expect? Their fashionable character has also been consistent. Classic Charlotte, bold and outrageous Carrie, sexy and promiscuous Samantha and Miranda the straight-laced.I loved that the movie was set in an unfamiliar (but just as fabulous) place and out of the old New York "box." It shows that these hardcore New York ladies (who had believed that everything you could ever want is right here in New York) have really grown.I much enjoyed this movie and honestly wished it hadn't ended. I think a lot of people just wanted to see drama drama drama "Carrie cheated! They should have had sex!" But no, I found this movie to be very modest, comedic, and true to the growth of the series and the women.------- In response to "Sex and the Shitty" writer jcdugger."Big" is not a nickname after his member. If you've seen the very first show of the series, it is understood that "Big" refers to his "big shot" status as the next Donald Trump.The series is not called Sex and New York, it's called Sex and the CITY. They mentioned Abu Dahbi is rapidly growing be the next capital city of the world.

Review title: Even Flat Soda can still be sweet
Review_body: Once upon a time four women lived in New York City. They had (we assumed) in the past battled law school, the demanding city, and were now facing a battle they may not win: finding happiness. The year was 1998 when we first heard Carrie Bradshaw write her column from an apartment that was only to be seen for one episode. In this first season, Carrie and her friends now had to fight their thirties, leading to an onslaught of emotional wreckage and failed experiments. Then the series matured and moved beyond its titular book. Suddenly, new layers were revealed, seemingly extracted between our imaginations and the lines of Candace Bushnell's prolific book. Sadly, the stories woven expertly by Micheal Patrick King came to an end in 2006,and while we would miss our favorite four women and their expert outfits, at least Carrie and Big found each other. We thought we would never hear those famous four notes again...Then, the summer of 2008 offered fans an extension. A chance to meet with our old friends. We found they were older, and not necessarily the wiser for it. Carrie was happily(unmarried) with Big (John Preston), Steve and Miranda were stuck in the terrible twos of marriage, Charlotte York-Goldenblatt and Harry were raising a daughter and Samantha was still with Smith. The thirties having been conquered, now the women had to face dealing with the forties. This journey left viewers with a heart wrenching story of love and forgiveness, a story that stood unparalleled and seemed to make this series only shine more. And even if it was now over, we had our happy ending.It was when a sequel to such a firm movie was announced and I was filled with questions, even dread: what would it be about? Where else could the series go? I am not disappointed with the latest saga to the Sex and the City. It is not a sequel so much as it is a homage to everything that made the series relevant in the first place. Where SATC 2 succeeds is that it does not rely on conventions of the rom-com genre planted thick with Meg Ryan substitutes. Instead it crafts a story that is woven with the brightest thread imaginable, and even attempts to answer the elusive question of "What happens after the guy gets the girl"? If anything, the new SATC was a pilot to a show leaving us with many questions: Will Samantha trick menopause? Can Charlotte really cope with two children and a bouncy, bra-less, and buxom twenty something? Will Miranda strike a balance between her need to work and her love for her family? All those questions however, are dwarfed by the most important question: do Carrie and Big have what it takes or was Bushnell's prolific work right in casting them as two people who will never find true happiness?The first act of the movie is a tale of domesticity. It is all about marriage. From Liza Minnelli reminding all the single ladies to put a ring on it, to the overdose of gayness in the gay wedding of Stanford and Anthony, and the struggles that each women endures in her now domestic home life. Not surprisingly, we need a movie, and all the women are not happy. It is this unhappiness which leads to a second act as the SATC girls, Danny Kaye and Bob Hope go to the Middle East. It turns out that the distraction they longed for was not completely welcome. Each woman faces her issue and finds her own way to conquer it. The montage like pace may seem like its a cheap excuse to show off the creative costumes but in the end you are left feeling like if there was a fantasy world, you've found it.That is truly where SATC 2 wins. It creates a charming fantasy in excessive overtures. With a lack of subtlety that is only a gleam in comparison to the arty violence of 300. That being said the movie is not without weaknesses. It would do better as a pilot for a new TV show rather than a full length movie and ran just touch too long. Two hours would have been fine.In conclusion, Sex and the City 2 proves that even flat soda is still sweet.

I took a break yesterday to see SETC2, and I have to say, the reviews have it totally wrong. I thought this movie was great fun, and I actually think it was much more true to the spirit of the series than the first movie. I thought the script was classically well crafted. There were dashes of politics mixed with a Carrie-esquire look at the challenges that arise in maturing relationships, and the whole thing was wrapped in the high-fashion confection we've come to expect from the show. I felt the characters, who had wandered off to weird places in the first movie, were back in fine form--especially Samantha. There are cornball turns of phrases, insider jokes, and winks and nods, but again, this is all very much in keeping with the original HBO series. If you're expecting Fellini, then this ain't the flick for you. But you should have already had 10+ years to figure that out. If you want an eye-popping 2-1/2 hour joy ride with some old friends, then go plunk your money down worry free.

Review title: Not Great... but not bad either
Review_body: So after reading plenty of reviews on the movie, my mom and I still decided we had to see it for ourselves,despite most reviews being negative. Being a SATC fan through and through the trailers definitely peeked my attention but I was a bit disappointed to find that most of the "OMG" factors had been given away in the trailers. Taking the girls out of NYC was not a great idea and didn't help the story line once so ever. It had its funny moments, it had its dragged out moments and it had the same old SATC moments. It was definitely NOT as good as the 1st movie, but it is still worth going to see. I hope for SATC's sake they do not go forward with #3.. there is only 1 thing left they can do with Carrie, and it was ruled out in the 2nd movie. Do not discourage from bad reviews, see for yourself. I enjoyed it, more or less.

What happened to this series?It was a great show but now they are just milking it. The dialogs was horrible. Who ever says things like that? Lawrence of my labia?! The acting was bad too. The characters were believable before but now. Urgh. Every time they were talking it feels like it was "forced". The sound track however is commendable. I don't why they went "ballsy" on us and tried something different in the movie. Fans want to see this because they get a sense of nostalgia in it. Doing something different destroys that.If you liked the show in anyway STAY away from this film. HORRIBLE HORRIBLE!Watch the entire series on DVD and watch the first movie. BUT PLEASE STAY AWAY FROM THIS ONE! I think Marmaduke will be better than this.

Honestly, I don't get the bad reviews.It is "Sex and the City" so you shouldn't expect a big story line. You are there to see the shoes,the cloth and man. The wardrobe budget was in the range of $10-million so it's worth seeing!!! Just for that it is 10/10! Abu Dhabi scenes were filmed in Moroccowas because they were denied the shooting permits based on moral objections to the movie's name -- "Sex and the City. And lots of people have a moral objections with the script hence the reviewsWe go to the movies to escape reality not to hear about the recession. Its a pure pleasure not a documentary on National Geographic for goodness sake! The show was so popular in first place as pure escapism. So just watch and enjoy it.

Review title: What the critics are not going to understand
Review_body: I have never written a movie review before, but I am honestly too frazzled with the extraordinary ignorance of "critics." I will be the first to admit that the execution of this movie could have been better; I would have liked to to see greater development on Miranda and Carrie's story lines (they missed a great opportunity there.) I do not believe the movie built an adequate momentum to support its very promising premise. Additionally, I think they should have fleshed out how Big stepped-in to quell Carrie's concerns. This movie speaks to the very old axiom about the cathartic nature of reaching life-long goals, the accompanying fears and writing the rules for your own relationship. Personally, I have been in many relationships that have defied convention, the approval of my friends/family, and even sometimes, my own beliefs. This is part of the learning process. (Men typically will not understand this as they expect women to conform to their man's expectations, thus they don't think anything of the difficulties women endure in "shrinking to fit.") Everyone has been disappointed by an achievement or milestone not delivering the happiness it foretold. Honestly, it is so easy for everyone to hop on a "bandwagon," following "critics" more concerned with how their insulting barbs enhance their own reputations, as opposed to critically evaluating intent and execution. With regards to the "racist" nature of the movie, the fact of the matter is that what was portrayed was accurate in terms of Middle-Eastern Culture- women are REQUIRED to dawn those garbs, and Samantha commits an infraction that MANY Americans make by attempting to impose her American culture over the customs of a foreign country. The accusation of racism was made by persons pertaining to that faith and culture, because it is portrayed pejoratively when juxtaposed with American standards. This movie is a Valentine to anyone who has ever feared life's many transitions, not being able to meet new challenges, and/or loosing themselves in the process.

I have just been to the Cinema watching Sex and The City 2. I must say I am originally middle eastern.To all the negative reviewers saying it was offensive to middle east, I must say I enjoyed the movie so much and it wasn't offensive at all. In my opinion, it only shows how open-minded USA is in accepting women sexuality and how close-minded Middle East is with regards to accepting sexual freedom to women. At the same time, I think they made middle east look much more glamorous than what it really is. Thanks to the power of Hollywood.With regards to the movie itself, I think it was funny, very colorful, glamorous and beautiful. I loved loved loved the clothes, the material and the fashion they used were astonishing. Yes, they magically solved all the issues without creating too much drama, but is that really that big a deal? What's wrong with knowing that sometimes, the dramas that we make for ourselves aren't really that big a deal, and there could be happy ending??I don't think they showed Carrie as a bad character and Big as a good character, they showed that men become boring after marriage, and also showed that Carrie was honest enough to admit even the slightest fling she felt with Aiden.I am not a fan of drama myself, I have loved Sex and the City TV shows for years, I own the DVDs and watch them all the time. I personally didn't like the first movie that much because I think it was very sad,, ,but the fun came back with the second movie.In my opinion: Samantha was fabulous as ever, she didn't want to change herself for anybody else, and she had the courage to stand up for herself in the middle of angry men. Miranda was brave enough to quit her job and show the hand to her abusive boss, and at the end, after taking some time off for herself, she found a better job where the atmosphere was more accepting to the person she really was. Charlotte as usual was her sensitive self, and Carrie was creating her own rules.Love the independence in these women and I hope one day I could be that independent.

Review title: I don't get it - I LOVED IT!
Review_body: Let me preface this with I'm a Sex & the City fan. Big fan. Watched all of the seasons at least 4x each. I would watch them before getting ready for work for fashion inspiration! I could watch them all again right now. That's it, I'm going home...I feel like I'm going to be hit with designer imposter bags for saying this, but I REALLY enjoyed the movie. I liked it better than the first one! My girlfriend felt the same way. We were talking about all of the parts we loved on the way to the car, to our friends, to our work pals.Ouch, put the talons away harpies. I don't understand why everyone is so disappointed. I laughed, I guffawed, I even got the vapors at moments. I even spoke out loud when I was laughing, and please note, that is not typical behavior for me. I flippin' loved it! Yeah, New York wasn't featured as a key player this time. But when it comes to big cities and fashion nowadays, there are trendier cities people! Some times NY gets tired. But I also loved the LA trip, the Paris trip, and the Hamptons in the series. I think featuring the UAE was very cool of them.Everything was so over-the-top and lavish! I feel that is what defined what Sex & the City in the beginning. The fashion and the lifestyle. Colorful, decadent, unattainable, unaffordable, fabulous! And when they did the 'real' moments with the girls, I felt connected to them on a more realistic level.I think this movie gave me everything - the fashion, the sex (which wasn't often, but hey, they've grown up a bit) the shopping. Maybe the original SATC fans have just changed and become more conservative...Ladies? Possibly? I thought the movie was fun, hilarious and extravagant. Plan on seeing it in theaters again and buying the DVD. Love 'em all and their blessed faults.

It's shameful, it's not even a bad movie, it is insulting to anyone with a little bit of intelligence.

Glamour, excitement and a plot that - in the end - almost turns a chick flick into an action movie. The papers are full of articles titled "Why I won't be seeing Sex and the City 2" but I'm here to change your mind. Two years on, the 4 BFFs have moved on from their single lives and face pressures from husbands, employers, children and nannies. Of course, Samantha doesn't have to worry about any of these as she remains a wild child throughout the sequel. The first part of the movie is "all work, no play" for all 4 characters whereas the second part is set in Abu Dhabi where "PARTY TIME" begins! Over-the-top details include Liza Minnelli singing a Beyonce song (which is also kind of genius) and Arabic women wearing the entire collection of one of the highest priced brands. If you think it's too much then you can prepare yourself in advance because it doesn't get more out of hand than that. Wilder, yes, but more out of hand, no! Most movie critics tell us what a disappointment this movie is, but we have to face facts: the sequel topped the first film and even the series! I might not be talking about the profit the newest addition to the franchise have made but the storyline is certainly more exciting. Maybe it's just me and all those sparkly accessories blinded me, but the first time left me craving for more and I am already planning my next visit to the cinema. Stop reading those bad reviews and stop giving yourself excuses why you shouldn't invite your friends to come and see this blockbuster with you. It's worth every penny and even if it doesn't – you know the rule -, you won't know until you try! By Alexandra Pamukov, a wanna-be movie critic

With all due respect, I am very appalled and surprised about all the previous reviews stating disappointments over this second Sex and The City Movie sequel. I understand like most, that the idea of being filmed outside New York seemed absurd at first.But after watching the movie today, I am glad that it did provide a refreshing and visually stimulating location and worked to benefit the plot of the movie.The first movie was about catching up on what these four women have been up to after the series ended and this movie reflects the substance of what REAL Sex and The City fans look after: unconditional friendship, love, with all the drama,frivolous wit and sense of humor spruced up with the latest of fashion.I feel that each character was portrayed in its essence. I am glad that the message of Sex and The City is still intact: an ode to women that feel to live life with irreverence, defying society rules with power, strength, independence and freedom!

Review title: An excellent movie, Funny and thought provoking
Review_body: I loved this movie. Like many women who have had children I found the scene with Charlotte locking herself away from the kids so familiar as would many other mothers. Samantha, thank heavens, was still her great self. The 'one liners' that have been written for this character have stood the test of time.
