The fashion was magnificent. I was pleased to see that they resurrected some of the previous outfits for this movie.Hilariously deals with ,menopause, religion, men, marriage and life. Job well done

I have been so excited about this film since it was announced that a second film was being made and wasn't in the least bit disappointed. Chris Noth has previously described this film as a "romp" and that's exactly what it was: comedy entertainment with a vein of insecurity from each of the women, as we have come to expect from the series. The uniqueness of this film as opposed to the series and the first film was the discovery of how Big feels about Carrie and marriage. His journey, I feel, makes this film fantastic. Big offers the audience a different view of Carrie - a male point of view, something not usually present in SATC - and this complements the story in Abu Dhabi, of how the women are completely muted in a strictly male dominated society. Those who criticise the film of being racist are clutching at straws and obviously have no understanding of the premise of SATC - like the series, this film invites discussion about changes in the women's lives and the barriers that they have to overcome for happiness in life and relationships. They never condone Samantha's behaviour and she is, in fact, encouraged to abide by the law of the country by the other girls. The depiction of the Abu Dhabi women is not malicious and is merely a comedic device to alleviate the strict lives that these women are obliged to live. The setting, while important to a degree, is merely a backdrop for a comfortable display of the girls' deep bond with each other, occasionally being tried and tested, but ultimately, making them untouchable. By bringing Aidan back, an alternative view of marriage and the idea that festers occasionally in a marriage that the grass may be greener on the other side, is not just felt by Carrie. While this film may not be as serious and emotional as the first, there are still emotional parts. Who wouldn't be moved by Chris Noth's depiction of a devastated man when Carrie tells him she has kissed Aidan? Chris Noth's increased presence in this film, I think, shows a possible new direction for another film. While the SATC brand is, and should always be, about the girl's and their friendship, Big's role in this movie makes it brilliant and he should be more of a fixture in the future. This movie does exactly what it says it will: it is Sex and the City as we know and love!

Review title: I would like those two and a half hours you took from my life back, thank you.
Review_body: Alright, I went to this movie because my friends wanted to go. I've never seen the TV show, I haven't seen the first movie (and now know to set fire to it if I see it on sale at Big W)- I went expecting the worst. And that's exactly what I saw. The characters were flat, predictable and downright unlikeable. The jokes were all terrible innuendos aimed at those clearly not capable of intelligent thought. The costumes changes were gratuitous and ridiculous (again, I know it's about the fashion, but as another reviewer said, numerous costume changes DO NOT CONSTITUTE A PLOT). Speaking of which, what plot? The four women deal with their issues in a way that's... no hang on, they don't. Sorry. My mistake, conflict resolution is dealt with magically here. Then they arrive in a completely different culture and take the term ethnocentric to a whole new level. They insult the locals, change costumes, whine, commit adultery, change costumes again and then are sent home, where they proceed to change costumes (I didn't see that one coming). I must say the lowest point of the movie for me, personally, was when Charlotte (who was, admittedly tired and under stress) completely lost it with her daughter and yelled at her for getting icing on a skirt- in other words, for behaving like any child would. The idea that a mother should favour a vintage skirt over her own children is wrong- are we really this materialistic?? I beg you, please, you are better than this. Only if you have ten dollars in your pocket that you found on the pavement and a spare two and a half hours that you would otherwise spend sadistically torturing small animals should you see this movie. And even then, you might want to think about it.

I was shocked when I saw this movie. When it opened and you saw the girls in their 80s garb I really thought there would have been more to it, not 30 second flashes of them looking just how you thought they would look. The general disregard Samantha had for Middle Eastern customs is just disgusting, from her skin-baring outfits to groping the foreign business man at the hookah bar, I was embarrassed to even watch her behave in that manner. Miranda was almost as bad with her attempts to speak the language. And Charlotte being afraid to use her last name Goldenblatt because they were in the UAE was the most offensive. I am very upset with the portrayal of Aiden, they turned him into a better-looking version of Big. I was excited at first when I heard he was in this movie, but after seeing how his character was written, had I known it would have worked out the way it did I wouldn't have bothered seeing it.The "fight" scene with Big (if you can even call it a fight) was poorly done and his way of accepting Carrie's apology I felt was lame. Heaven forbid a married woman should wear a wedding ring! Oh my what a punishment. All in all I am super disappointed in the whole thing. The Liza cameo was so painful to watch, even though it was at the start of the movie I was tempted to leave after that scene. Don't waste your money, it's not worth the $10 you're going to spend, rent it one night and save yourself the money of seeing it in theaters.

Disrespectful of the Muslim culture. To a degree where I felt it was down right racist. A vehicle to promote fashion brand Halston Heritage, Christian Louboutin, and high street favorite Zara. The characters were so far removed from their former selves they were a parody of the 'people' we had come to know so well. The film was a massive disappointment from start to finish, perhaps the shiny shoes (stilettos in the desert, in the SAND!)and flashy fashion was supposed to distract us from the lack of substance. Carrie & co sold out. I physically recoiled at Samantha's behavior in the souk. Miranda was the only saving grace. I don't know why they made it, well I do, money money money, but it has left most fans I know feeling put out, and let down by people that had become such a permanent fixture in their lives over the past decade. Needless to say I will not be purchasing the DVD when it is released!

Review title: It was WAY better than all the bad reviews said
Review_body: Despite all the horrendous reviews, I decided to see the movie because a friend of mine said it was good. Still, my expectations were very low. So I was surprised by how much I liked it--- even my husband admitted it was fun. One of the biggest complaints about the movie was where Charlotte and Miranda ask each other how they could possibly raise children without help-- and then they give a toast to women that manage to do it without nannies/maids. It wasn't condescending-- it seemed very real. And, something most women who have help never consider. And while the plot was a little far-fetched-- it was nothing compared to your average James Bond movie where the whole thing is more made up than any fairy tale.Overall, I am glad I went. If you're a fan--go with a group of friends, knock back some cosmos before hand, and enjoy it for what it is-- a fun summer movie.

Review title: he movie would be enjoyable if I was a 16 year old stuck in a body of a 50 year old woman..
Review_body: I have been the fan of the original show for years. Unfortunately, I have to say that "Sex and the city 2" was more than disappointing.. In this film ironic and even sarcastic humor that distinguished the show from the others is gone...The show just got so old that humor vanished along with Samantha's estrogen.. The characters are dull, the story line is boring and some of the scenes are just stretched.. In my opinion - the movie would be enjoyable if I was a 16 year old stuck in a body of a 50 year old woman.. Producers should have left the legend of "Sex and the city" be. Instead of completing the show this movie leaves a bad taste in your mouth. The main character Carrie not only got old from the outside, she got rotten from the inside as well - instead of living happily ever after she still focuses on the small things making an elephant out of the small marital problems. Since she obviously is not happy and not even young and beautiful, the producers decide to go back to one of the old story lines - Carrie meets her old love in the middle of the Middle East. Not only is this storyline unreal, but it is unnecessary as well.. The character Samanta..well lets just say that free spirited femme fatale was the FATAL error in this movie. Not only was she boring, her sex scene in this movie was just one close up away from the actual porn movie.. To conclude, I have to say, that if it wasn't for Miranda and Charlotte - the movie would have been a complete waste of time. I was really happy to see that at least two of the original four characters moved on with their life - found new purpose and new topics and the old wounds were not brought up. All and all the movie was disappointing..I will never like "Sex and the city" again..

Well, I went to see this one with my wife. I don't know anything about this series, but I was expecting a girl's comedy (that's OK, fashion, funny situations, not bad). And it began as expected, with funny situations and presenting four well educated, professionally successful, wealthy and independent women in their 30s to 50s (at least seemed to be the idea). Then it came the Middle East and the women started to act like teenagers from a poor neighborhood that just hit the lotto and the film became superficial, absurd and worst of all Boring. At the end went so bad that I started to think in films like "The Naked Gun" and "Scary Movie". I never understood any character; the "lawyer" looked like the intern of the firm and it seems she didn't gave a penny for his son and husband; the "mother" (who uses and expensive skirt to do pastry?) was just a flat character and not even funny ; the "publicist" was taken from a low budget x-rated film, vulgar, brainless, over the top superficial with a sex appetite that never was explained or even interesting; and finally the "writer" (because all girls movies should have one) was a cheesy, predictable and teen character. The end was beyond ridiculous with the Muslim women using "expensive garments" (the leader looked like a parrot) and hiding in a cheap market, I would guess wealthy women in the Middle East may have better places to be and may use more comfortable clothes for that weather (which can be expensive of course). Finally I will talk about men. They basically could be changed for clothes, accessories or even a pet and the history will be the same, but lets be fair, women in boys films are also for show up. SATC is a long, most of the time boring, superficial and silly comedy, if your girl like it, I would think twice to continue dating her.

Review title: Not good, definitely overdone but still fun to watch
Review_body: I get the reviews. I too was disappointed. But honestly, if you once enjoyed Sex and the City - the series, you will want to see it. To say it is a waste of money? Yes and No. Yes, the actors seem to have forgotten how to act. The shouts and screams seem over the top and the girls lost their fun interaction. But is seeing the actors of your once favorite show again worth a couple of bucks? Yes.Let's be fair. Was it worse than the first movie? Not really. At least now there is a story to tell, even if it is a bad one. Let's not forget that the first movie only had a story line because of mr Big's two minute pre wedding jitters. What story would we have had if Carrie had not exploded and made a big deal out of nothing. After all Big turned around almost instantly. For Carrie to act this way when he is the love of her life, seemed like a desperate attempt from the writers to get a story line.So.. with this new one, at least it makes more sense. And yes, the oversexed attitude of Samantha lost its appeal. And yes, Charlotte and Miranda looked old. And yes, Carrie became a whining wife. So one is right to dispute that the original characters just aren't what they used to be.But despite that, it is still Sex and the City and they are still Carrie, Miranda, Charlotte and Samantha. If anything the writers tried too hard to make them into their fun characters. Maybe they forgot that having these women on the screen is enough to please the millions of fans. We really did not need the writers to exhaust themselves over a script that is clearly overdone.If I were to say anything about this movie, it would be that it is overdone. But in some way I still enjoyed it, just because I got a glimpse of my favorite TV series and because of the vow I took to watch any movie,show or series that features these women together. Whether it is a disappointment or not. I will choose to forget the bad parts and remember the good parts. Even though that is a slight challenge here for Sex and the City 2.

I adored the TV series. I liked the first movie. I didn't mind the second movie...The character dynamic was twisted in this movie. Carrie has always been self centered and selfish, but she took it to a whole other level. Complaining about a TV being installed in her bedroom was bizarre, and obviously the writers were fishing for anything for her to complain about. They could have gone in a totally different direction with this relationship (economic decay = relationship decay) but they wanted to keep it "lighthearted". Miranda may have well not even been in the movie, along with the husbands, because she was barely noticeable. I did relate to Charlotte's woes somewhat, being a mother of 2 and all, but the fact that she has a full time live in nanny, a housekeeper and a seemingly wonderful husband just made her seem desperate for screen time when she complained.Samantha is a disgusting character in this movie. Absolutely disgusting. She had one very funny line at one point in this movie and the rest was crap. I can not believe that an actress like Kim Catrall would agree to what the writers/producers/directors asked her to do. Disrespectful doesn't even begin to describe her behavior in this film. I won't waste any more time talking about her because she doesn't deserve anything after that performance.As for the fashion, I didn't really notice it. A lot of people complained about too much fashion, ugly fashion, whatever, but I didn't find it to be all that important...which probably means I don't really care about fashion to begin with.AND, it's 2.5 hours long. Too long.With all that said, if I ever had to kill 2.5 hours and I had some girlfriends over with a couple bottles of wine, I'd watch it again. But there would HAVE to be wine...

Review title: Loved Sex and City Movie 2. You cannot always rely on reviews!
Review_body: Sex and The City Movie 2 was a delightful display of all the characters that made the series so great The story line was interesting, and seeing another area of the world was not bad but good. The movie made you laugh,and put forth great memories of the series. Sex and the City Movie 2 explored fantasy, intrigue, and restated each of the characters. The clothes worn by all the girls were relevant to each of the four, and were just as bizarre in some scenes as the previous movie, and the series. Everyone played their part well. I just don't understand why the reviews were so negative.I do hope there is a third movie. Maybe the series should be reunited!

I am, like most the review writers, is a fan of the HBO series, so of course, the earliest time I could see the movie, I rented the DVD and with a great expectation, I watched. This movie just made me want to cry. I guess the time really does not pass on any and really leave marks. I guess the edited pictures of the move made me think that after all these years, the girls still got it. I watched the last movie 2 years ago and the foursome still looked OK. But this time, I was really startled, scared, ambushed by screen after screen of each actor's fading face. Big, he is still charming but his face is starting to look like a senior citizen. Carrie, I don't know why she is still into big bushy hair and big skirts at her age, she really looks like a witch. With her skinny face, it looks even more gruesome with her eyes look smaller ever and cheek bones sticking out. Charlotte, she is still graceful but with her aging face, she should not dress like 35 anymore to make her look don't fit with her dress. Miranda, she is still put together but when at one scene when she turned around with a frowning face, her cheek looks like it was going so down it was going to fall out of her chin. The only actor in there that does not show as much sign of aging is Aidan, boy when he appeared, it was such a cool air in a hot sticky day, he still looks the same, maybe a bit darker, face - a little wider, but at least it does not look like it is falling apart or looking like a skull with rotten skin on it. Finally Samantha, she is losing her face definition and she looks like a grandma at best but she still acts like a crazy woman. I couldn't resist to check on their ages and found that they are not so old yet, 45, or 55. Aidan is 49 but he looks the best. I really think these actors should take the responsibility in taking care of their appearance, 45 looking so old and 55 looking like a senior already is crazy. Isn't 45 the new 35 and 55 the new 45? Their face look like the their wax sculpture is melting and their face is rapidly melting away and they are still walking around.Overall, the style is still the same, glamorous, women issues with great hair and great outfit, but that really need some great face and great attitude to carry that, or it is just one big disgusting stinking act. I saw there are already a lot of bad reviews but I just cannot stay quiet and not say how disappointed I am with the movie.I really hope this movie does not come out the III and these characters can rest in peace to leave us the nice memories.

OK...I tried to enjoy this film, which was challenging at times. The first two or three minutes were promising. The wedding was kind of cute, even with Liza Minelli singing one of Beyonce's songs. Then the story gets awkward. Big gets hit on by some guy at the wedding, and Carrie thinks it's hot. Then, Carrie and Big meet a married couple who seem to be convinced that all married couples should have kids so they won't be lonely. More awkwardness...Carrie and Big spend a nice night watching an old movie, in spite of Samantha and her sexual olympics and Charlotte's screaming 2 year-old, so Big decides to get Carrie a wide-screen TV in their bedroom for their anniversary. Heck, I wouldn't like a TV in my bedroom either. Carrie gets so upset over the present and Big's talking to a hot banker chick (even though it was OK for a cute guy to flirt with him?) that she has to go away to her apt to write (didn't she do something like this to Aidan in the TV series once?). Then she gets confused when Big suggests that he have his own little place to go and chill.Samantha gets a call from Smith to go to some party with him (another thing that was a let-down for me..I wanted to see more of Smith!!) Sam gets introduced to an Arab prince who offers her and her friends an all-expenses-paid trip to Abu Dhabi. Samantha jumps at the opportunity and convinces her friends to come with her.When they arrive in Abu Dhabi, Samantha whines when customs takes her hormones away. Oh no! It's the end of the world! Her face will melt...her vagina will dry up! *heavy sarcasm* Couldn't she have checked what she could and couldn't bring through customs ahead of time? Another thing she seems clueless about..or simply doesn't care about..take your pick, is the ways of middle eastern culture. Most of the trip is fun, quaint and irreverent. The ladies ride camels, Carrie bumps into Aiden in a market, Miranda and Charlotte have a *itch session, and Samantha ultimately gets arrested for nearly having sex on the beach with a hot Dutch guy. Public indecency much, Samantha? Really?? Is it the hormones?? Then the ladies have to make a mad dash to get out of Abu Dhabi before being forced to spend their own money on another night at the hotel. Uhm, couldn't these ladies have afforded it? Anyway, Samantha gets involved in one more moment where her bawdy sexuality nearly gets her in trouble, but she and her friends are saved by a group of women. And I thought it was pretty cute and sweet that the women were wearing the entire Versace spring collection. lol Then the ladies go back home and realize their lives aren't all that bad after all. Carrie and Big seem to reach a reconciliation, Samantha gets to have sex on a beach undisturbed, Charlotte stops worrying about her nanny after she discovers that her nanny is into other hot nannies, and Miranda goes to a new firm where she is respected and appreciated. A nice neat ending that left me feeling a little like the filmmakers were trying too hard.The film did have occasional cute and sweet moments that were overshadowed by way more awkward moments. I thought the clothes were great, but the appearance by Miley Cyrus was a little trite. Carrie and Samantha seemed too spoiled and selfish at times. It's far from being the worst film I've ever seen, but certain plot points and characters could've been better developed. The first SATC movie is way better than this. I don't think it's a total waste of time to see SATC 2, as long as one keeps in mind that the film is just for fun, and don't think about the inconsistencies too much. Although after reading many reviews on this page, that might be difficult. I would like to see a third film of SATC, but ONLY after the filmmakers ensure that they have a good plot worth putting on film. I would like to see a recovery from this slip-up, and have the franchise end on a high note.

Review title: Awful way to end a fantastic series!
Review_body: Wow. What a disappointment. Most all of the intelligent dialogue and interesting, adult problems from the series are gone. Basically, they just all run away from their problems and act stupid in a foreign country. Who on earth thought it would be a good idea to get away from New York?! The whole point was that they were set in "the city." I didn't care to see Abu Dhabi -- that was totally pointless. There are a few real problems that are touched on, but mostly the four of them are just running around acting dumb. And the wedding at the beginning as well as the karaoke scene later on are overdone and painful to watch.Samantha used to be funny, but here she's just a total whore (worse than the series if you can believe that) and embarrasses herself all through the Middle East. Her only serious issue is that she's aging -- they could have made some interesting dialogue about that, but it's all stupid jokes about hormones. Carrie's problem involving seeing her ex could have led to really interesting dialogue. Miranda and Charlotte's issues also COULD have led to interesting dialogue. But that's all left out. Where is the introspection that made the series so fascinating? Leave out all the Abu Dhabi crap and get back to the women dealing with their problems there in the city. They used to have real character. This leaves out all of those moments of grappling with real dilemmas that made the series so fascinating. Stupid jokes, dumb outfits and people acting like whores used to be minor comedic extras in a series that was introspective and about adults dealing smartly with problems (divorce, infertility, breakups, extramarital affairs) in their fast-paced New York lives. It used to be so fascinating to watch. I hope to forget this awful ending.
With few exceptions, most of the scenes were boring.

even with 2 margaritas this movie was still too stupid. I am so thankful I read early reviews, so I didn't pay good money out of pocket to watch these 50 plus women (btw, I am 52) trying to be 25 again. I waited for it to be shown on my premium movie channel. Seriously, I am so glad it did this. There are too few redeeming moments. Not enough to override the corny nonsense.Please! As an addict of the original sex and the city -what a disappointment. Please, please movie people: No sex and the city 3!! It would be too sad to watch more of these 50+ women pretend to be in their 20s. Sad sad sad.Katherine

Review title: Oh the horror!! Not worth watching on cable!
Review_body: So bad I literally can't get through it. Having recently been to the middle east - I can't express how appalling the obvious and not really funny jokes and observations they put out there. I'm hoping it didn't go far internationally as it's truly embarrassing to Amercans.What the heck happened? From costuming to makeup this movie was beyond "off." Did the directors and producers suffer brain damage that made them approve the dailies for this piece of crap?Everyone looks old tired and uncomfortable. Way older than they are by the way. Dressed ridiculously for anywhere - much less a trip to the middle east. Aiden was the only one that looked like he was traveling on earth. The rest were fashion victims of several IDIOT stylists. The plot was actually worse than a combination of clichés from the smart series. From an over the top gay wedding to Samantha conning some Emir into a lavish trip. It's not fun even if you watch to ridicule it. Several drinks might not even help.Here I sit - painfully watching this train wreck on HBO - apparently with a horrible karaoke scene coming up. One gets the sense that every member of the cast realized what a dog it was and barely acted. I guess every actor needs to round out their accolades with a razzie or two huh? Hope they cashed in on this one as I'd bet their phones stopped ringing the minute this came out.There's two and a half hours of my life I'll never get back...Save yourself! Don't even bother to watch it.(And that's the reason I bothered to type this review.)FYI - I did manage to get to the end of this horror completely sober. However tempted I was to get stone drunk to see if it would get the bad taste out of my mouth. It wouldn't have helped anyway...My final conclusion: The producers became so tired of this concession that they murdered it. How do you KNOW there will be NO SATC3? By charging admission to this insulting garbage. And I mean insulting to every stripe of viewer, fans, the subject matter, the location and the poor actors. Don't worry. No one will be asking about another SATC movie. While I'm personally neither here nor there about Kim Catrall, SATC2 gets the prize for giving an actress the worst stereotypical "unlikeable and stupid slut" role I've ever seen on film. I was actually embarrassed for Catrall in the second half. The directors and writers get the "Idiot" for thinking it could play as campy. If we're lucky, we never have to see any of their work again in our lifetimes. Yech!

Review title: Worst movie I've seen in years....and I've seen A LOT of movies...
Review_body: I am fully convinced that the summary of the review says it all.anyway other than the fact that it was an extremely boring movie (and I am a patient person)I really hoped that somewhere along the 2:20 hours way thing would definitely improve. oh how wrong I was...the scene that crash and burned to the ground my expectations was when the Arab women unveiled their "new spring collection" outfits. Review title: If you don't expect much, enjoyable enough
Review_body: OK, I was the fan of the original SATC series. When I saw the first movie I had high expectations and was left extremely disappointed and appalled, at how spoiled and selfish the four women I had loved and looked up to in the original, came to be portrayed as. I felt betrayed and angry then. So by the time this second movie came out I knew better - not expect much at all. I watched it simply to enjoy seeing their colorful lives once more, and to satisfy my own curiosity for what more the writers had in mind for the continuing lives of these four girls. That attitude worked for me, and I enjoyed it for what it was. I chose to ignore the elements of the movie that many people here are saying as offensive by not taking this movie seriously; it's not worth it. It's like when a movie is made out of a book, it's best to not compare the two but see them as two separate entities; the SATC movies and the original series on HBO... are two different things. Expect this to be a movie to be watched purely for entertainment purpose, for passing time, and not something that will teach you valuable life tips or inspire, as the original series did. If you go into it with high hopes you'll most likely end up feeling betrayed. If you choose to see it not so much as a movie but as a silly two-hour long reality escape on a DVD, it is not so bad.The movie does not have much of a storyline, but there were two things I appreciated: the plot on Carrie with her doubts about her happy-ever-after, and the exchange between Charlotte and Miranda about their motherhood. Carrie's acting out on her fears and her subsequent coming-clean to Big, was true to her character - fallible, and still lovable. The way Big handled their little crisis at the end, showed well in the short scene, that he had matured as a man from the once perpetual bachelor. Charlotte and Miranda sharing honestly with each other what they felt as their own flaws and shortcomings in their motherhood was touching, and true to their bravely honest characters from the originals. As for Samantha, well, unfortunately her over-sexed character lies flat and boring; her integrity and intelligence that was once well-deserving of respect in the originals, is forever lost in the two sequels. Final verdict: if you can see past all the flaws in this movie, and choose to see it just for fun, it can be enjoyable enough. If you have a hard time detaching the sequels from the original series in your mind... it might be best if you skip this one (or the first one).

Review title: it wasn't too bad of a movie but could have been better.
Review_body: I think if they would have put Richard Wright and Samantha back together again it would have been a 10 out of 10...they were such a awesome couple and he showed a side of Samantha that her vulnerability as a women and a softness that I have never seen her with anyone else that she has been with in any of the Sex And The City's..I hope they do a Sex And The City 3 and they add these two lovers back together again...I would love to see them finally together just like Big and Carrie...By putting these two together again is the only way I can even see a Sex And The City 3 ever happening...and that is just my opinion...

Review title: Looking for a funny movie without an ounce of reality?
Review_body: First of all, the Sex and The City franchise has ALWAYS been known not to be realistic ~ four wealthy NYC women who are always in each other's lives who never have a boring moment for a nanosecond. If they're not sleeping with a gorgeous guy, they're sipping cosmopolitans, eating at a high-end restaurant, shopping at Gucci, or doing SOMETHING that is flat-out entertaining. Every single TV episode was like that, as was the first film. Obviously, this movie sequel is just that, and then some.This movie is pure escapism; nothing more, nothing less. It's not meant to be taken seriously!The 4 characters who lead ultra-extravagant lives get an all-expense paid trip to a middle- eastern country and are treated like royalty, complete with their own floor at a 5-star hotel, their own butler (who can only leave when dismissed) and their own chauffeur. That's pure fantasy, every girl's dream to be a princess.Samantha's character, as always, delivers the funniest lines/situations in the film. When she's caught having sex on the beach, gets arrested, and the girls eventually have to leave for the airport, a woman dressed in middle-eastern attire shoos the girls into a secret room, where other middle-eastern women are hiding. And what do they reveal? The latest fashion from the USA.Many people didn't like this movie because it's not the least bit realistic. Again I say: the Sex & The City TV show and BOTH the first movie are simply the daydreams of every American girl.If you want a movie that will make you laugh and take you away from your everyday life for 2 hours, then this is the movie for you.

As I sat in the almost empty theatre I realised fifteen long minutes had gone by while watching the poorly conceived Sex and the City sequel. Glitzy, glamorous and geriatric, I couldn't help but wonderwas this the best they could do? The reaction to the second film has been mixed at best, but still I was curious as to how this new instalment in the SATC franchise would unfold, so I bit the bullet and sat through the whole film. All ill-judged 146 minutes of it. The wry wit and passion of the television series has long burnt out and now we watch 4 privileged, wealthy, middle aged women, moan and whine about the dull and difficult role of being a career woman, a mother, a semi-newlywed and a menopausal cougar.These women live in the most exciting city in the world, they have amazing opportunities and for the most part they have everything they could ever have wished for. But of course, it's just not enough for them. Whilst the television series was thought provoking and risqué, this insipid sequel lacks any of the shine and pep of the original incarnation. At least when we watched the show weekly we had time in 40 minutes to laugh, cry, cringe and marvel at the antics of the fiery foursome. Now we are subjected to a mid-life crisis of four older women with a dynamic that has gone stale. There is no sympathy anymore for these women when their lives falter at the slightest hurdle. They are in the minority of women who do have it all and their lives are far and away more glamorous than the likes of us, so to witness them wallow in self pity and despair for no good reason leaves a sour taste in the mouth. We don't even have the typical backdrop of New York City for most of the film. The absence of this iconic character is felt even before our intrepid seniors venture to the (unnecessary) location of Abu Dhabi for business and pleasure.Speaking of which, for a show that is famous for using sex as a major theme, there was very little to be had in this film, which added to the lack of sparkle that the series and first film offered in spades. Instead we have personal journeys and oestrogen talk that really fails to light a fire in the hearts of die-hard fans. By the time the "action" moves to the desert we are sucker punched with more designer looks than a head to head between Amir Kahn and Karl Lagerfeld. Unfortunately, the most glaringly obvious must-have found in this film is a life time supply of botox.Perhaps the reason why the film didn't work (or one of many) is because in the beginning, every twenty something girl to every forty plus woman watched these friends like they were our own. We related to them, we wanted to be like them but in the end - even with the fairytale – their problems turn out to be the same as us mere mortals.In spite of a script devoid of laughs and sentiment, I am sure the cash will roll in, making the third instalment a likely outcome. If that means Gucci Zimmer frames and Swarovski encrusted Rascals roaming the streets of New York (or wherever), count me out.

Ugh. This movie was abysmal. I was a fan of the series, it was cleverly written and because of it's popularity , the writers had years to develop the characters and layer experiences that created depth to each one . Well, p*ss on all of that work. This movie managed to turn these well loved characters into hideous caricatures. Prepare yourself for two long hours of cringing.I'm embarrassed for poor Kim Catrell. She proved her worth as an actress for years through the Samantha character, but here they have taken the fag-hag trope, over painted it and smeared it with gaudy cheap glitter. The bag of flamboyant one liners they gave her to dish out added a whole new cheapness to the "cheap laugh" category. Prepare yourself for juvenile fashion montages in the desert? and with the heaviness of hearts I must say ..the fashion didn't make up for the absurdity. Oh sorrows!! What's the point then? The Carrie and Big storyline was such a snore, I decided to mop my floor while watching the rest - I'm not kidding. I didn't rent a SATC movie to trudge through the daily monotony of someone else's marriage- I've got my own. It's not that it wasn't a worthy subject but certainly not one to base an entire feature length movie upon.I agree with a previous reviewer's opinion that the Charlotte storyline was a bit insulting considering they gave her a full time nanny. Yes, mothering is hard, harder than we all knew before we signed up. Sometimes we snap from exhaustion no matter what our income level, but I'll tell you, peeking into that window through the eyes of someone with full time help isn't going to earn you any points with the majority of women who are paying to see this movie because I'm willing to bet the majority are doing it without help. They should have perhaps written the nanny as having to go out of town or something- and Charlotte then has to handle mothering alone. I could have then maybe accepted her "How do mothers do it without help?" as more of a compliment than an eye roll. Miranda's character lacked depth but I suppose they let her exhibit the full range of emotion in the last movie so was just a prop in this one. Steve, once again, just like the first movie, lacked so much depth that they could have substituted a broomstick with a plaid shirt and a smiley face on it. And at some point between this and the first movie, the Big character had his balls removed. I will pretend this movie never happened.

The series was great and the first film was a perfect ending to the story. This film however, is racist and sexist and portrays the women as shallow, selfish, vacuous, offensive, ignorant and astonishingly lacking in self-awareness. The characters always had heart but now they just have a massive sense of self-entitlement, and it's ugly. Whoever wrote and approved this script should be ashamed of themselves. Plus, it's full of glaringly obvious product-placement. The only bit that's any good is when Raj from Spooks pops up. Other than that, all I can say is go and watch something else that won't make you hate characters you love and eventually yourself for putting up with it.

Review title: Tagline for this movie should be: Shopping and stuff like that are Cool, but Charity and hungry people across the world aren't

Were there any money involved from wealthy Sheikh to promote Dubai and Abu Dhabi? I have heard some news that things aren't going so well as they planned. Is this some kind of commercial?

Review title: Not the show, not the first, but fun!
Review_body: Many criticize the girls for being "whores" and saying they send the wrong message to females today. In the early seasons of the show, I would attest to this, but throughout the later seasons, the first movie and the second, I would argue that the girls have matured, taken responsibility for their lives - except for Samantha, who remains the wildest of the four, even after her serious relationship with Smith.The New York sequences are perfect; after all, it's where the girls belong. Even Abu Dhabi wasn't terrible, until Samantha's arrest. From that point on the plot felt convoluted and rushed. This, about half an hour from the end of the movie, however, didn't ruin the rest of the movie, which realistically deals with life after marriage, life after kids and even the tough reality of the workplace. I was thrilled to see Aidan's return, I have always been an Aidan girl. However, as with Smith's appearance,I felt it was mostly just thrown in there for some familiar old thrills from the show. If Aidan had been brought in earlier in the plot, his story line would have been much more strong and enjoyable.The movie isn't perfect, it's very different from the feel of the first, and even most of the shows. However, throw caution to the wind. Put on some heels, go with the girls. Don't think you're going to see the movie of the year (you're not) - think you're going for fun - which you are.
Why was that film so slow? Every scene was like torture. Not funny. Plus the clothes were ugly.

Review title: definitely not a happy hour (or 2 and 1/2!)
Review_body: I have never written a review of a film before on this site, but watching this film has made me so angry and disappointed that i felt i had to say something.I am 23 and like most girls have loved the sex and the city TV series and the first film, so was very much looking forward to this second instalment I went to see this with my mum and a friend and her mum, we are all different ages, and not one of us had a good time, or could say anything positive about this film when we left the cinema.It has little story line, and the 4 girls who i loved watching in the first film, now seem just shallow and completely devoid of normal human reactions/emotions and behaviour.The way the women act in Abu Dhabi is embarrassing and completely disrespectful to the countries culture.Basically don't waste your money on this hyped up piece of fluff, the outfits may be nice to look at, but there is no substance at all.

Listen folks...if you are looking for something of substance here, look elsewhere, but I just left the theater with my husband (who's A SATC hater) and we had a really good time!! I laughed so hard at certain points of the movie and I'm still laughing! Everyone in the movie theater seemed to be having a good time. I grew up with these four girls and some of my friendships were identical...and that's what we loved about the show, and that's why we go to see the movies. As women, we do see a lot of what we've been through on screen. Are the girls still hot? I would say that they look great for their ages! We are all growing older and I think that they are still looking pretty good (wrinkles and all). I think that anybody would definitely give them all a second glance if they saw them walking by. Enjoy it for what it was and what it is, a good time out and a few great laughs. As for the situation with Aiden, who hasn't ran into an ex boyfriend/girlfriend and had those thoughts? For the serious SATC fans, you will absolutely adore this film. The wedding was hysterical and Liza was looking and moving around pretty good. I for one feel that it was definitely worth the price of admission and for my husband who I had to beg to go with me; he actually thought it was pretty good too!

.....This film was like an extension of the scene in series 6 with Geri Halliwell - awkward, confusing, embarrassing and leaving you scratching your head wondering why anyone thought THAT would be a good idea? I was disappointed then and was equally disappointed after seeing this flick. The saving grace for the cringeworthy Spice Girl scene was that it was only a minute long. This, on the other hand, lasts for 2 hours+!Thank god I paid for a Premier seat as there was lots of squirming to be done! Wheeling Liza Minnelli on to do a number at the start (since she struggled to even get the shortest of lines out) sets the tone for what's in store.....a jaw-droppingly mortifying piece of clichéd, 'chick flick' (yuk), over-the-top cinema.As well as seeing Samantha act like a drunken auntie at Christmas (pelvic thrusts, racial slurs and drunken karaoke included), you have cheap puns and unbelievable characters with even less believable motivations. To then set this charade anywhere other than NYC would be mystifying but to set it in Abu-Dhabi truly boggles the mind. Especially when it's clear the writer knows little more about the United Arab Emirates than the rest of us living in cities in the Western world.Now...I'm not daft and I know that even the most casual SATC fan is going to head along to the pictures with their girlfriends (or a very unfortunate boyfriend / husband) no matter what the reviews say. So all I can do is say this...do NOT expect anything more from this film other than 147 minutes of ridiculousness. If you're prepared, you may even have a giggle or two. If you're a huge fan of the series and are expecting more of the same (which, in my opinion, wasn't even delivered in the first film), just stay home, watch the boxset again and pretend this movie doesn't exist because - if you do put yourself through it - you'll be doing that at the end anyway.On a positive note though....at least they're weren't any bleedin' montages in this one!Now, that's fabulous!

As I search for the words to describe this film, the only image that comes to mind is the migratory mating pattern of the Medusa Jellyfish. That's to say, this thing is a slimy, sexually-frustrated, formless blob of viscera, slowly meandering across an ocean of ineptitude and disappointment.When discussing the plot of this film, it would be more appropriate to say that the presence of a plot would be a welcome addition. However, when the writers of "SATC2" were tasked with deciding on what the message of the film would be, they seem to have landed on a portrayal of the comings-and-goings of four corpses that can't seem to find the politeness of being actually deceased."Production quality" is a term that should be forbidden when discussing this movie, as "quality" suggests the existence of any discernable effort to making the piece enjoyable in any way. Unfortunately, it seems as though the lighting crew decided that a better use for the burning cigarettes used to light the first act were better-utilized by being jammed into their own eyeballs. At least, this would save them from having to witness the betrayal of cinema unfolding before them.Character development is...In summation, the viewing of this picture could be considered as a torture method for the most radical of global terrorists, were it not for requirements for humane methods of the Geneva convention. After viewing this piece, I am thankful that I am not imbued with the ability to will myself out of existence, as I can't say with certainty that I would be alive otherwise to write this review.

Review title: What happens in Abu Dhabi should've stayed in Abu Dhabi
Review_body:
The only watchable thing about this movie is Kim Cattrall. And that's with an awful script. As it has always happened with SATC. But this one takes the cake.
I'm being nice.

Review title: The girls are back on top form
Review_body: What can I say........ This film really really did impress me. It was a non stop fun filled movie, with bundles of laughs thrown in and set in some amazing locations. All the actors/actress's were on top form, especially Kim Cattrall. It was nice to see Miranda become a more bubbly and fun character too in this movie. I wont go on about this film, but if you want to see a great movie with everything in it then this is for you. I walked out with a lot of other people all smiles :) I don't think it would be right to do a 3rd movie but a 7th brand new series would be spot on. Well done to all of the cast for bringing us such a great movie. Cant wait for the Bluray to be released now

This probably takes the spot for number one most awful film away from Tango and Cash. I feel like I was robbed of 3 hours. Carrie is a whiny, unsatisfied, typical Jewish princess when her husband gets a TV for their anniversary and she tells him she would rather have jewelry. She is looking old and stupid in the fashions. The black hat she wore to the wedding made her look like Cruella from 101 Dalmatians. And the blue hat on the plane made her look like a revolving appetizer plate from a Mexican Restaurant. Samantha is just disgusting. She needed to be douched with Lysol years ago but now she is just an old "whore". Miranda and Steve were great and Charlotte, burdened with two kids, had the best and only good line in the film. When she thought her husband may take off with the Nanny, she thought, "Oh no, I can't loose the Nanny." There was a very thin story line filled with ridiculous situations that were so over the top suspension of disbelief was impossible. It was pitiful and the old ABC after school playhouse movies were written and executed better. It reminded me of the plot-less series called the Monkees back in the 60's. Mindless, gratuitous, convoluted,idiocy.It was just on TV. If I paid money to watch it I would demand a refund. Terrible movie. Just terrible. Boring. Ridiculous. And if you ever liked Carrie or Samantha you might hate them after watching this.

This is possibly one of the worst movies I came across, everything about is terrible, the movie has no plot or a story, alot of things doesn't make sense,horrible representation of UAE like it's Iran or something, even fashion in this movie had it's low points.What is thi?

Review title: Abudabi the movie! and 4 STRANGERS come to visit!... Nightmare and Im the BIGGEST FAN!!
Review_body: I would like to make it clear that i am one of the biggest fans of this show since it began, i waited a day in Leicester square to see the premiere and i have never stopped loving it until now. i have been urged to write this review after seeing a few "so called" fans saying they enjoyed this film.The film started really good the marriage between Anthony and Stamford was such a shock but a good shock. i expected to see how this marriage would go.but none of that happened.they got married then nothing. smith comes back and you think maybe he could get back with Samantha. he never shows his face again. I don't even remember seeing Steve or harry in the film.i felt that the film began with a few interesting stories like Charlotte's nanny which could have developed. but no you see her breast twice and then 2 hours later it just turns out shes a lesbian.The main problem was that if they had stayed in new york which is the "city" of sex and the "city", then maybe the film would have been good but instead the majority of the film is an Abu Dhabi. and the whole time I'm just waiting for this holiday to finish so they get back to the story.except they come back 10 minutes before the end of the film.So what happened to Aidan, they kiss then thats the end of him!! so many little stories were started but never completed!! And who have these girls turned into! Samantha get fired from her job thing for breaking the Abu Dhabi kissing law, i always thought she was professional. they are all racist talking about the face scarfs and Samantha giving the finger!.Carrie stupidly causes the problems for her marriage when shes the one always trying to make things perfect! and is mean to Charlotte in the elevator for no reason. it just feels like nothing happened they began a film then filmed the whole core of the film with Abu Dhabi.. they could have developed the idea of Miranda having problems with her boss, but instead she just quits in the first 5 minutes. and they don't even show that scene, just Miranda telling Steve about it! It did have some funny bits.but what good are a few jokes at a funeral. and the camel toe just isn't that funny compared to Charlotte shitting her pants!! I hope that a 3rd film is made that makes this all better!!

Review title: Appalling, embarrassing stereotype of both US and Arab Culture
Review_body: Didn't anyone have any doubts when they read the script? Four rich, spoiled, white American girls behaving appallingly in a stereotype version of Abu Dhabi - "the Arab world". Cringe. I'm not sure why I watched it all, I was on a plane and could've changed to something more worthwhile, but I was transfixed.The only surprise was that it could get worse than when it opened with the 4 women whining about imaginary difficulties in their lives: (1) There is something wrong with poor Carrie's marriage because her and Big don't feel and behave in exactly the same way as when they first met. (2) Poor Charlotte who doesn't appear to work has a beautiful nanny. (3) Miranda has the only thing that could be considered a real problem, a misogynist boss. Cured by throwing a hissy fit and giving up the job without any real fight. (4) Sorry, can't remember what "problem" Samantha had.But wait until they start heading to "The Arab World". Then it really spirals downhill becoming not only trite but just so uncomfortable. This should be required viewing for any terrorist faction wanting to stir up hatred for America or white women in general: This is what Americans are, this is what they think of us. Unfortunately it has to be seen to be believed. Really the cast should have turned up for their Razzie award. Come on guys, show some remorse.

Review title: Waiting for the DVD might not even be worth it.
Review_body: I will come out and say this first: I do not closely follow the Sex and the City series and have never been a huge fan of the show. But after living with sorority girls and having a girlfriend who loves the show, I've been exposed to it enough to tell you that Sex and the City 2 is far under par for what the franchise is capable of. The film is just empty; what little plot there is seems to be very loose and inconsequential. I just can't say the film went anywhere, and I gained little, if anything, from it. Everyone I went with--all avid fans--were just as disappointed as I. Save your money now and rent it later.

This movie was seriously terrible, and the reason for that was simple: the characters we see in this movie are not the characters we know.Usually what made this show great was that you could, at some point in your life, identify with one of the four characters. But simply hearing Carrie say to Big when he gives her a TV for their anniversary that "hmm, jewelry would have been nice" made me cringe. At least his present was from the heart, since the story behind it was that he enjoyed watching an old movie with her the other day. To be honest, Big is usually not the kind of character I would ever see settling down and being "controlled" by a woman, so to me, he did an awesome job. I mean, after a long day at work he decides to make Carrie happy and go with her to a movie premiere. I mean, c'mon, this guy is doing everything to make her happy. And what does she do? Complains all the time and then cheats on him with Aidan in a foreign country. This movie made me hate Carrie, the whole time I kept thinking she was acting like a spoiled 16 year old. At no point did she stop to think. I mean,even though she was never perfect in the series, she was someone who would stop and ask herself rhetorical questions every five minutes. For someone with so much experience in relationships, she was so stupid. The other characters were also equally dumb, Miranda was maybe the only one that was still half normal.All in all, I just wish the producers of this film would have stayed true to the characters and focused on what really mattered instead of trying to impress us with a bunch of superficial things, which in the end, made everything in the movie look shallow.

Review title: One of the worst pictures I've ever seen
Review_body:
I love the series. Movie number one has a special place in my heart. It's the perfect heartache flick.
But this one?! Oh no ... Don't do it. Don't watch it. You can never unsee it!
Why would they do it? Even the acting stank at times. No. Just no!

I am not sure what is wrong with everyone....I absolutely adored this movie. I got to do exactly what I wanted-laugh and cry with the characters like always....sure, Samantha was rude in a foreign country but come on people. She is who she is, that is exactly who she has always been because she is addicted to sex. I loved, loved, loved everything about this movie, including the singing, the clothes, and the plot. I thought it was very well done...even if it was a little slow moving at first. And for all of those who say Carrie was selfish-of course she was. That is also who she is. I think you people need to re-watch the seasons before you accuse the characters of being nothing like they were before. I think they were exactly who they always were and I am so glad I got to see this movie. Thank you for Sex and the City 2...hopefully there will be a 3.

After the first movie, which I thought was super depressing, I was really happy that they were bringing back the comedy! These scathing reviews are rampant, so I thought this movie was going to bite the big one. I had a great time and was never bored and LOVED the Middle Eastern journey, which was ripe with comedy. People saying the movie disrespected the culture of Abu Dhabi is laughable...most of these people have never even been to that part of the world, and know nothing of their culture, or what it's like being an American woman there. And they seem to be hating on the actresses themselves, not even the characters...If Will Farell was walking around Saudi Arabia with his shirt off, people wouldn't have said anything about how inappropriate he was being in a Saudi country, but because they're women.... Anyway, don't forget this is an HBO series turned into a film. I'm glad it wasn't all complicated like the first movie, I can see a drama for that. I thought it was awesome and would see it again, two nipples up.

I am very late to see this movie as it came out years ago. I'm a big fan of the SATC series and enjoyed the first movie. But I have no idea what this was? What a disgraceful interpretation of these characters. It was on the local cable network and I tuned in. I can see why Kim Cattrell refused to do a part 3. They absolutely butchered her character. She must have walked out of the final editing of this film feeling terrible seeing herself like. In fear she may never be taken seriously again. Being sexually liberated is very different than being portrayed as a desperate easy woman.This movie was culturally offensive, like middle aged women would go to a foreign country and behave like morons... They completely undermined any kind of business savvy or smarts these characters had in the series with the exception of Miranda. In no way would 40-50 something year old women behave this way. What a disgrace of a film. Carrie's character just came across as being rude, selfish and self-centered, to her husband and to her friends. Their was nothing cute, endearing or funny about her. At the end I was hoping BIG would divorce her for being such a selfish brat. This was a writing disaster, the acting was forced trying to bring a script to life that in no way reflected these characters. The make up and acting was terrible. And that karaoke seen gave me a "Oprah you are embarrassing me" feeling. Watch if you must, but expect the ridiculous.
